Can-do statement: Can form simple affirmative declarative clauses.
Example:
I study English at college. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2007; Mandarin; Pass)

My friend is a nurse. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2006; Panjabi; Pass)

I'm living in Manchester. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2009; Kurdish; Pass)

It's very cheap and you can buy all you need. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2008; Italian; Fail)

He is very nice but sometimes he is a little crazy. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2006; Italian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can combine a negative clause with an inverted clause with 'nor', to give focus.
Example:
That night Kevin did not sleep; nor did Kristin. (Spain; C2 MASTERY; 1999; Catalan; Pass)

They do not have any hobbies, nor do they have friends or relatives (at least not where they live). (Sweden; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

Her diary was never found, nor was Juliette. (Netherlands; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Dutch; Pass)

I should never have agreed to meet him, after all I didn't know the man nor did I understand what he was talking about, but he really said my friend Peter was in danger, that's what made me say yes. (Portugal; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Portuguese; Fail)

Can-do statement: Can form a simple negative declarative clause with lexical 'be' + 'not' or 'n't'.
Example:
My college is not very big. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2007; Polish; Pass)

This place isn't big. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2007; Lithuanian; Pass)

I'm not bad. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2006; Panjabi; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can form simple negative declarative clauses.
Example:
I don't like maths. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2007; Farsi; Pass)

I don't have children. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2008; Polish; Pass)

I don't know. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2009; French; Pass)

Guideword: FORM: AFFIRMATIVE DECLARATIVE, MODAL AUXILIARY VERBS
Can-do statement: Can form an affirmative declarative clause with modal verbs.
Example:
I can go to see her tomorrow. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2009; Panjabi; Pass)

I will visit you soon. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2009; Kurdish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can form an affirmative imperative with the base form of a main verb.
Example:
Goodbye. Write soon. (Russia; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Russian; Pass)

Bring your swim-suit for the swimming pool. (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Spanish - European; Pass)

Call me if you need anything. (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Spanish - European; Pass)

Guideword: FORM: NEGATIVE DECLARATIVE, MODAL AUXILIARY VERBS
Can-do statement: Can form a simple negative declarative clause with modal verb + 'not' or 'n't'.
Example:
I know you couldn't come to my party so I want to tell you about my presents and party. (Turkey; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Turkish; Pass)

I can't wait to see you and tell you the rest. (Argentina; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

You won't have to bring anything. (France; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; French; Pass)

When I worked in the sushi bar, I could not eat lunch and dinner at the normal time. Sometimes I ate lunch at 3pm and dinner was at 11pm. (A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Japanese; Pass)

Once you have started, you will not want to stop. (Hong Kong; A2 WAYSTAGE; 1999; Chinese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can form a simple negative declarative clause with auxiliary 'have' + 'not' or 'n't' and 'have' + 'not' or 'n't (got)'
Example:
I haven't eaten Italian food for a long time. (Ecuador; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2003; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

� now I haven't got any money. (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2005; Spanish - European; Pass)

I bought them because I hadn't got any clothes for summer. (Turkey; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Turkish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the auxiliary verb 'do' in an affirmative declarative clause, for emphasis and affirmation.
Example:
Yes, I do have a favorite restaurant. (Mexico; B1 THRESHOLD; 2005; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

I do miss you. (Syria; B1 THRESHOLD; 2002; Arabic - Levant; Pass)

I do apologise for the change but I can't be there on the 28th of June. (Italy; B1 THRESHOLD; 2003; Italian; Pass)

After all, you did say that you wanted go somewhere with your friends. (Turkey; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Turkish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the imperative to give instructions.
Example:
Take a taxi to the Petrol station then call me. (Libya; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Arabic - Meghreb; Pass)

The easiest way to get to my house is by Underground. Take line 14 and then change to line 8. Walk a little bit more and then you arrive. (Brazil; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Portuguese; Pass)

Wear an apron over your clothes. (India; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Hindi; Pass)

Bring some money with you. (United States of America; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Russian; Pass)

Take a yellow bus near Green Park at 5.45 pm. Remember to bring your camera! (Italy; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Italian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use negative imperative after an instruction, for emphasis.
Example:
Our house is next to the school and my home is opposite the post office. Don't forget. (Tamil, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2009)

We'll meet at my house at 3 o'clock. Don't be late! (Brazil; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'let's' + base form of a main verb, for first person plural imperatives to make a suggestion.
Example:
The concert will be in Canec�o. Let's go!!! (Brazil; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Portuguese; Pass)

Let's go to the town centre, it is an interesting place. (China; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2001; Chinese; Pass)

Let's meet at half past four. (Romania; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Romanian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can form a negative imperative with the auxiliary verb 'do' + 'n't' + base form of a main verb, to give advice, instructions or orders.
Example:
Don't tell Lucy, please. (Mexico; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Don't bring your children please. (A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Slovak; Pass)

Don't worry, I'll be there. (Slovakia; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Slovak; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the imperative to give instructions, often at the end of a letter or when saying goodbye to someone.
Example:
Email or phone me. (A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Estonian; Pass)

Write to me soon. Take care. (Malaysia; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Chinese; Pass)

Come soon. (Italy; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Italian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'let's not' + base form of a main verb to make a suggestion.
Example:
Let's not lose track of each other again! (Brazil; B2 VANTAGE; 2004; Portuguese; Pass)

Let's not forget that zoos actually help us keep dying species alive �. (B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

Let's not make the situation more complicated with companies and things like that. (Greece; B2 VANTAGE; 2009; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'do' + base form of a main verb, for emphasis or in formal contexts.
Example:
Do write back and let me know all your news. (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Spanish - European; Pass)

Do let me know your views on this. (India; B1 THRESHOLD; 2004; Others; Pass)

Do follow the instructions. (India; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Gujarati; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the imperative to make an offer or an invitation.
Example:
Come and visit us after the New Year, we've got so much to talk about. (Somali, B1 THRESHOLD)

Come and stay with us this weekend! (Turkish, B1 THRESHOLD)

Can-do statement: Can use an imperative clause with 'let me' + base form of a main verb, as a focusing device, to introduce something
Example:
Let me tell you my story. (Taiwan; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Chinese; Pass)

Let me explain something. (Russia; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Russian; Pass)

Let me answer your question. (Libya; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Arabic - Meghreb; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'do not' for emphasis or in formal contexts.
Example:
Do not forget to have a break at lunchtime and try to eat your meal whenever possible in a silent room. (Switzerland; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; German; Pass)

Do not hesitate to contact me should you need further information. (Chile; B2 VANTAGE; 1998; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Guideword: FORM/USE: 'LET' + THIRD PERSON PRONOUN, DEVOLVING RESPONSIBILITY
Can-do statement: Can use an imperative clause with 'let' + 'him/her/them' + base form of a main verb, to devolve responsibility.
Example:
Let them find their own food. (Portugal; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

But she put aside her friends because she didn't want to be pitied. After few attempts her friends gave up."Let her live alone". (Poland; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Polish; Pass)

So let them be and let them scrutinize the peculiar events that do occur in life. (Sweden; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

Guideword: FORM/USE: 'LET' + THIRD PERSON PRONOUN, PERMISSION, ORDER
Can-do statement: Can use an imperative clause with  'let' + 'him/her/them' + base form of a main verb, to  give permission or allow something or instruct someone to allow something.
Example:
Try to play chess with him whenever you can and remember: Let him win! (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Greek; Pass)

While in London, they want to do their shopping there, so let them have more free time to do that. (Poland; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Polish; Pass)

If she wants to study away from home, please, let her go . (Poland; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2010; Polish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use imperatives to point within or to a document within formal contexts, often academic.
Example:
See enclosed brochure. (Sweden; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

As you requested in your memo, I have spent the past few days gathering information from the six students involved in our programme (see above). (Catalan, C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY, Pass, 2000)

Look at the graph of the Agricultural sector 1991-2001. (China; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2002; Chinese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use an imperative clause with  'let' + 'him/her/them' + base form of a main verb, to disallow something or instruct someone to disallow something.
Example:
Don't let them spend all their free time in front of the TV. (Sweden; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1999; Swedish; Pass)

Don't let him go out alone, because he may not feel well. (Portugal; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use imperatives to introduce a condition followed by 'and' to introduce a consequence of the condition.
Example: See one of them and you'll want to see them all. (C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

Guideword: FORM: AFFIRMATIVE INTERROGATIVE, WITH MODAL AUXILIARY VERBS
Can-do statement: Can form interrogative clauses ('yes/no' forms) with modal auxiliary verbs.
Example:
Would you like to come with me? (Argentina; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2005; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Will you go with me? (Russia; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Russian; Pass)

Can I come tomorrow to collect it? (Poland; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2005; Polish; Pass)

Shall we meet at 7.30 pm? (Switzerland; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Swiss German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use you with an imperative form to make an instruction stronger.
Example:
Don't you ever do that again! (Cyprus; C2 MASTERY; 2001; Greek; Pass)

Don't you dare! (Portugal; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Don't you dare forget me, I want letters from you promptly, understand! (Korea, South; C2 MASTERY; 1998; Korean; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can form interrogative clauses ('yes/no' forms) with auxiliary 'be' and 'have'.
Example:
Are you going to the new art class? (Cyprus; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Turkish; Pass)

Have you got a new dress for the party? (Italy; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Italian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can form interrogative clauses with 'be'.
Example:
How are you? (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2009; Farsi; Pass)

Are you ok? (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2011; Thai; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can form interrogative clauses ('yes/no' forms) of main lexical verbs with auxiliary 'do'.
Example:
Do you remember Julie? (Brazil; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Portuguese; Pass)

Did you buy a new mobile phone? (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can form 'wh-' interrogative clauses with a 'wh-' word as object.
Example:
When are you coming here? (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Spanish - European; Pass)

What have you bought? (Turkey; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Turkish; Pass)

And what must I bring? (France; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; French; Pass)

When can we meet? (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2005; Spanish - European; Pass)

Where did you go? (Vietnam; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Vietnamese; Pass)

How  do you feel? (Thailand; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Thai; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'What a pity' + ('that') clause.
Example:
What a pity that you didn't come. (Brazil; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Portuguese; Pass)

What a pity you lost the information about the new art class. (Cyprus; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'What a' + noun phrase and 'What a' + noun phrase + clause.
Example:
What a brilliant idea. (France; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2003; French; Pass)

What a nice present I have! (China; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Chinese; Pass)

What a great afternoon I had yesterday! (France; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; French; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can form questions with a 'wh-' word as subject, without an auxiliary verb.
Example:
What happened? (Spanish - Latin American, B1 THRESHOLD)

Who cares? (Spanish - Latin American, B1 THRESHOLD)

Who knows? (Portuguese, B1 THRESHOLD)

Can-do statement: Can form negative interrogative clauses with an adverb in mid position, between the subject and the main verb.
Example:
Money - hasn't it always been one of the most important problems for students? (Japan; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; Japanese; Fail)

Why don't you ever listen to me? (Sweden; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

Haven't you ever heard about the photographer Donatela and the painter Christian? (Greece; B2 VANTAGE; 2001; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can form interrogative clauses with an adverb in mid position, between the subject and the main verb.
Example:
Have you ever been to Marseille? (France; B1 THRESHOLD; 2001; French; Pass)

What kind of books do you usually read? (Italy; B1 THRESHOLD; 2005; Italian; Pass)

Do you still remember my best friend? (Vietnam; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Vietnamese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can form negative interrogative clauses.
Example:
Isn't it great? (Switzerland; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; German; Pass)

Don't you like pizza? (Burmese, A2 WAYSTAGE)

[Talking about a car] I bought one. Didn't I tell you? (Portuguese, A2 WAYSTAGE)

Can-do statement: Can form negative 'wh-' interrogative clauses.
Example:
Why don't we watch a film? (Sri Lanka; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Tamil; Pass)

Why didn't you come with me? (Bulgaria; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Bulgarian; Pass)

Why don't you ask Jennifer to go with you? (Uruguay; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2003; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Why couldn't you come? It was fun. (Malaysia; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Chinese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'How' + adjective.
Example:
How exciting! (China; B1 THRESHOLD; 2003; Chinese; Pass)

How terrible! (Bosnia-Herzegovina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Serbian; Pass)

How amazing! This is my first flight in a hot-air balloon. (China; B1 THRESHOLD; 2003; Chinese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'How' + adjective + clause.
Example:
How lucky you are to have visited that exhibition! (Switzerland; B1 THRESHOLD; 2007; French; Pass)

How lovely to get your letter. (Iran; B1 THRESHOLD; 2004; Farsi; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a defining relative clause with 'who' as the subject.
Example:
It's about a girl who went to the war when she was 22 years old. (Mexico; A2 WAYSTAGE; 1999; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

I'd like a pen-friend who really likes music and reading. (China; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2002; Chinese; Pass)

I can tell you that I agree with people who think that Stonehenge is magic place. (A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Polish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a defining relative clause with 'which' as the subject.
Example:
At the end of the game, the KASAS sang to Hagas a piece of music which makes me cry. Suzanna watched with me and she cried alot. (Brazil; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Portuguese; Pass)

You should wear clothes which can get dirty. (Switzerland; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Swiss German; Pass)

I bought a t-shirt which has a picture of a car on it and I bought a shirt for my brother. (Turkey; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Turkish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the negative interrogative form of an auxiliary verb to express surprise or enthusiasm.
Example:
Wouldn't it be wonderful! (Russian, B2 VANTAGE)

Doesn't that sound excellent to you?! (Denmark; B2 VANTAGE; 1999; Danish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a defining relative clause with 'that' as the object.
Example:
The team that I like is called 'The Monkeys', but Paty prefers 'The Walls'. (Uruguay; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

I bought some clothes that I will need for my trip to Greece. (Cyprus; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Greek; Pass)

Please, wear clothes that you can get dirty; use old clothes, okay? (Brazil; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a non-defining relative clause with 'who' as the subject.
Example:
I watched it with my brother who was also interested in sports. (Malaysia; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Chinese; Pass)

It's given by Jenny who is one of my best friends. (China; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Chinese; Pass)

I want my mobile before this afternoon because my parents who are in Japan will call me. (India; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2005; Tamil; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'How' + clause.
Example:
How I often longed to play with the other children or relax with a good book. (Germany; C2 MASTERY; 1993; German; Pass)

How I love the smell of home! (Brazil; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

How I long to be there again. (Netherlands; C2 MASTERY; 1998; Dutch; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a non-defining relative clause with 'which' as the subject,.
Example:
I bought it in Peter's Mobile shop, which is near to my home. (Sri Lanka; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Tamil; Pass)

I've been to Cardiff which is the capital city of Wales. (Korea, South; A2 WAYSTAGE; 1999; Korean; Pass)

I visited a museum and an exhibition which were really excellent. (India; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Tamil; Pass)

I bought two shirts, which cost �20 and four sweatshirts, which were a little expensive. (KET; A2 WAYSTAGE; Pass; 2008)

The mobile phone is green, which is my favourite colour. (Turkey; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Turkish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'How' + adverb + clause.
Example: How differently we were brought up by our mother. (Germany; C2 MASTERY; 1993; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a defining relative clause with 'which' as the object.
Example:
I came to your house yesterday with the computer game which I borrowed from Mayank. (India; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2005; Hindi; Pass)

The coffee-cup which my good friend gave me is pretty. (China; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Chinese; Pass)

Sorry, I can't do anything to help because I will try again to pass an exam which I failed last year. (France; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2005; French; Pass)

The colour which I prefer is pink, so we will use pink. (India; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Bihari; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a non-defining relative clause with 'which' as the object.
Example:
The best of all was a marble statue which my aunt gave me. (Bangladesh; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Bengali; Pass)

Thanks for your letter which I received a few days ago. (Greece; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use defining relative clauses, 'the person who/that, the thing that, the (only) one who/that' as a focusing device.
Example:
The thing that was great is that the weather was really warm and it didn't rain. (France; B1 THRESHOLD; 2003; French; Pass)

The thing that I love most is going to the shops. (Peru; B1 THRESHOLD; 2001; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

The person who sat next to me was her. (Vietnam; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Vietnamese; Pass)

The person who called me was my best friend. (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Catalan; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use defining relative clauses with 'where' to define nouns referring to place.
Example:
The city where I live is very nice and extremely charming. (B1 THRESHOLD; 2003; ; Pass)

But if they are going to a place where you go every year you should go with your friends, you will have more fun. (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Spanish - European; Pass)

We went to the area where I used to live when I was a child near the Highlands. (Czech Republic; B1 THRESHOLD; 2003; Czech; Pass)>

Can-do statement: Can use defining relative clauses with 'when' to define nouns relating to time.
Example:
The day when he had to go back to Korea, I could not stop myself crying. (Korea, South; B1 THRESHOLD; 1999; Korean; Pass)

I really remember the day when I lost my suitcase in the airport. (Mexico; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

I was in the class at the time when they made the movie, so you will be able to see me on TV. (Poland; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Polish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a non-defining relative clause with 'who' as the object.
Example:
What I liked most was the friend I made there, a green-eyed chubby boy, who I played with till dinner time, when I had to go home. (Brazil; B1 THRESHOLD; 2003; Portuguese; Pass)

She turned around and, she couldn't believe it, it was an old classmate Tom, who she hadn't seen for ages! (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a defining relative clause, without a relative pronoun.
Example:
My friends said the clothes I wore were very old, and they didn't like them. (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Spanish - European; Pass)

All my friends gave me a present but the one I liked best was John's. (Portugal; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Portuguese; Pass)

Here I have the information you want. (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Spanish - European; Pass)

[talking about video calls] You can see the person you are calling LIVE!!! (Cyprus; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use defining relative clauses and non-defining relative clauses ending in a preposition, with 'who/which/that' as the complement of the preposition.
Example:
Thank you very much for having provided us with valuable information about your finance services, which we are greatly interested in. (China; B2 VANTAGE; 2008; Chinese; Pass)

I would like to do some painting, which I am quite good at. (Switzerland; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; French; Pass)

They have three wonderful children who I love to play with. (Sweden; B2 VANTAGE; 1998; Swedish; Pass)

He was involved in a case that he had nothing to do with! (Greece; B2 VANTAGE; 2009; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use defining relative clauses with 'why' after 'reason', to give an explanation and for focus.
Example:
The reason why I love it is that it's quite original because it's about a woman who can see ghosts. (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2007; Spanish - European; Pass)

This is the reason why we are changing our working hours. (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2007; German; Pass)

This is the main reason why it is so famous and popular as well. (B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; French; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a defining relative clause with 'who' or 'that' as the object.
Example:
My friends are the people who I love most. (Argentina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

They filmed two actors who I don't really know arguing and kissing after it. (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Catalan; Pass)

It was Sarah, a girl who I met in Spain on my holiday last year. (Switzerland; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Swiss German; Pass) 

We are going with my friends Paolo and Ontorio, the guys who you met yesterday. (Italy; B1 THRESHOLD; 2004; Italian; Pass)

So I sent a letter to the school and they have sent me the details of the people that I'm going to stay with. (Japan; B1 THRESHOLD; 2003; Japanese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use defining and non-defining relative clauses with 'whose name'.
Example:
We have a new employee whose name is Mary Watts. (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2002; Spanish - European; Pass)

It was a very famous football player, whose name was known all over the world. (Russia; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Russian; Pass)

I have many friends but I'll tell you about my best friend, whose name is Nicos. (Greece; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Greek; Pass)

He has got a friend whose name is Robert. (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2001; German; Pass

The man whose name I can't remember, wrote a serious looking message. (Switzerland; B1 THRESHOLD; 2004; Swiss German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use non-defining relative clauses with 'whose', to give additional information.
Example:
And I was initially employed to be an entrance assistant, whose job was to keep the queue under control as well as keeping the area clean. (China; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; Chinese; Pass)

I was at the concert when I met a friend of mine whose job is to organise shows like that. (Italy; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; Italian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use defining relative clauses with 'whose', to give more information about relationship.
Example:
I visited several primary schools in Canberra and had opportunities to teach not only Australian children but also Vietnamese children whose parents immigrated to Australia. (Japan; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Japanese; Pass)

Mary is a young lady whose parents had died and she had nobody else but an aunt to live with. (Brazil; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a finite subordinate clause with conjunctions ('even though, (al)though, while if') to introduce contrast, before or after a main clause.
Example:
You should come with your sister even though you would rather be alone. (France; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; French; Pass)

Even though I am currently quite busy, I will be very glad to take part in the Conference dinner. (Italy; B1 THRESHOLD; 1999; Italian; Pass)

Although he was famous, I didn't like him. (Chile; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Though we are not studying at the same school now, we always keep in touch. (Vietnam; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Vietnamese; Pass)

The main actor is my favorite actor, although I can't remember his name. (Taiwan; B1 THRESHOLD; 2002; Chinese; Pass)

I think going on holiday with your parents won't be very much fun, while if you go with your friends you will enjoy yourself much more. (Italy; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Italian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a finite subordinate clause with 'because', after a main clause, to introduce reasons.
Example:
I love her because she is friendly. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2006; Bengali; Pass)

I like my television because it is big and modern. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2009; Arabic - Other; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a finite subordinate clause with conjunctions to introduce reasons, after a main clause.
Example:
I prefer to speak on 14 July, as I have got another appointment on the next day. (India; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Malayalam; Pass)

I am going to be absent from my English class next week, as I am travelling to Italy. (Argentina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Unfortunately I will not be able to go to your class tomorrow since I have an appointment with the doctor. (Peru; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'this' + noun + 'of' + possessive pronoun to highlight something, often in a positive way.

This characteristic of his is shown in every situation of his life. (Brazil; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'those' with plural nouns. ? noun phrases ?  pronouns: demonstrative
Example:
The cost of those clothes was �300. (Malaysia; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Chinese; Pass)

I love to play those instruments. (Sri Lanka; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2010; Singhalese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use ''s' after singular or proper nouns to indicate possession.
Example:

I'll wear them at Linda's party. (Italy; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Italian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use possessive determiners 'my', 'your', 'his', 'her' and 'our' before nouns. ? noun phrases ? possessive pronouns
Example:

� my neighbours are very nice and helpful. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2009; Panjabi; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use quantifying determiners + possessive determiners + 'of' + noun. ? noun phrases
Example:

Can-do statement: Can use 'that' and 'those' to convey emotional distance, often to express disapproval.

Can-do statement: Can use ''s' after a noun phrase with of to indicate possession.
Example: Actually, I know a great one and they can make a little discount for us because the owner is a friend of my father's . (Albania; B2 VANTAGE; 2009; Albanian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 's'' after plural nouns to indicate possession.
Example:

So, if you want to study animals' behaviour, try to do it without changing the real circumstances in which they act! (Italy; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Italian; Pass)

The second reason is: it is too far from the children's school and, unfortunately, I haven't got a car. (B1 THRESHOLD; 2007; Slovak; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'their' before nouns to refer to a generic body or group of people expressed as a singular subject. ? generic pronouns
Example:
� yet everyone has their preference for one or another. (Greece; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; Greek; Pass)

Example:

Can-do statement: Can use possessive determiner 'its' before nouns to refer to a singular inanimate subject or object.

Guideword: FORM: SINGULAR NOUN ENDING IN 'S' + APOSTROPHE
Can-do statement: Can use an apostrophe after singular nouns ending in 's', to indicate possession.
Example: However, I believe that in order to maintain its popularity, the programme should keep some of the series' aspects the same, but alter some others. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2009; Greek; Pass)

Example:
Living in Greece, I have had a chance to realise how much tourism can affect one's life. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2007; Greek; Pass)

After one has spent enough time away from one 's parents and has a personality of one's own, it is definitely possible to move in with one's parents. (Romania; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Hungarian; Pass)

In my opinion, this process depends on one's ability to open another way of communicating apart from one's mother language. (Portugal; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a limited range of quantifying determiners with plural nouns ('some', 'lots of', 'a lot of' and numbers).

Can-do statement: Can use a limited range of quantifying determiners with singular nouns ('a', 'every').? determiners: articles
Example:

Can-do statement: Can use an increasing range of quantifying determiners with singular nouns ('each', 'an', 'one' and numbers).
Example:

Guideword: FORM: WITH PLURAL AND UNCOUNTABLE NOUNS
Can-do statement: Can use a range of quantifying determiners ('some', 'any', 'no', 'more', 'a lot of') with both plural nouns and uncountable nouns.
Example:

We danced, played games and had lots of fun . (India; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Gujarati; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use an increasing range of quantifying determiners with plural nouns ('all', 'both', 'a few').

This notice is for all students: we are going to have a concert at school. (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2005; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'many' with plural nouns in negative contexts.
Example:

Can-do statement: Can use an increasing range of quantifying determiners + 'of' + determiner ('half of', 'enough of', 'none of',).? pronouns
Example:

Guideword: FORM: WITH PLURAL AND UNCOUNTABLE NOUNS
Can-do statement: Can use an increasing range of quantifying determiners with both plural nouns and uncountable nouns ('most', 'enough', 'plenty of', 'loads of').
Example:

Guideword: FORM: 'SO MUCH', 'TOO MUCH' WITH UNCOUNTABLE NOUNS

Can-do statement: Can use a range of quantifying determiners + 'of' + determiner ('all of', 'some of', 'both of', 'many of', 'any of', number + 'of', 'each of'). ? pronouns: quantity

Can-do statement: Can modify determiners with adverbs. ? adverbs

Guideword: FORM/USE: 'MANY A' WITH SINGULAR NOUNS, FOR FOCUS
Can-do statement: Can use 'many a' or 'many an' + singular noun for emphasis and focus.

Guideword: FORM/USE: ORGANISING, MARKING NEW KNOWLEDGE, INFORMAL
Can-do statement: Can use 'you see', 'the thing is' as discourse markers to mark new knowledge, usually in informal contexts.
Example:
You see, in the park, you can enjoy fresh air� (Vietnam; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Vietnamese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use sequencing adverbs as discourse markers to organise text.

� Secondly, I know you like a healthy life so if you don't eat too much candy and unhealthy food, you can keep fit easily. And lastly, please believe in yourself, I know you can do it, and don't give up the exercise� (Turkey; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Turkish; Pass)

Finally, I would be grateful if you would arrange a car from this airport. (Russia; B1 THRESHOLD; 2004; Russian; Pass)

Likewise, in Nepal New Year is celebrated on 1st of Baishak, which is the start of a new year according to the Nepalese calendar. (B2 VANTAGE; 2011; Breton; Pass)

This group is expected to decrease considerably in the next fifty years. Similarly, the population of children are likely to drop to 11.5% in 2050. (India; B2 VANTAGE; 2011; Kannada; )

(Portugal; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a range of phrases as discourse markers to summarise.
Example:
Thus, I would be very grateful if you would send me clear explanations of the following points: firstly, I would like you to specify what �the normal price� is, and therefore what would be the cost of two nights. (Spain; B2 VANTAGE; 1997; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use adverbs as discourse markers to indicate an attitude or viewpoint.

Unfortunately, they filmed only the building and the garden, not the students! (Italy; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Italian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a range of phrases as discourse markers to point to other parts of a text.

Guideword: FORM/USE: ORGANISING, OPENINGS AND CLOSINGS, FORMAL
Can-do statement: Can use a range of phrases as discourse markers to open and close texts and point to conclusions, often in formal contexts.

Can-do statement: Can use adverbs in the front position for focus.

Can-do statement: Can use 'it' + 'be' + adjective + 'that-'clause for focus.
Example:

It's true that there are one or two programmes that are interesting or funny, but the rest... they're horrible! (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2010; Spanish - European; Pass)

It�s important that you are happy. (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use prepositional phrases in the front position for focus.

Guideword: FORM/USE: 'THE THING/ FACT/ POINT/ PROBLEM IS (THAT)'
Can-do statement: Can use 'The thing, fact, point, problem, or reason + is (that)' for focus.
Example:

The thing is, Alison is an eleven-year-old girl who has been, together with her father, left behind by her mother when she was just three. (Brazil; B2 VANTAGE; 2005; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'The reason (that)', 'The place (which)' + clause as subject + 'be' for focus. ? Relative clauses
Example:
The reason I am writing is to suggest a few things about our holidays. (Greece; B2 VANTAGE; 2008; Greek; Pass)

The reason that I never continued taking lessons is that my school-work became too heavy and the costs of lessons were too expensive for me as a student. (Sweden; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

The place you need is called "Academiuta". (Italy; B2 VANTAGE; 2005; Italian; Pass)

The place we appreciated the most was the Cap Frehel, where nature is still wild and the birds feel at home. (Belgium; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; French; Pass)

The place which has impressed me most of all in my life is Abastumani. (Georgia (Republic of); B2 VANTAGE; 1997; Russian; Pass).

Can-do statement: Can use fixed expressions in the front position for focus.
Example:
At the end of the day everything is up to you! (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2000; Greek; Fail)

All in all, the activity week was a nice experience for both students and teachers. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Greek; Pass)

All things considered, I would recommend the third proposal as it seems to me that it covers most of the points the students have been complaining about. (Italy; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1999; Italian; Pass)

When it comes down to it, who does not like such a surprise? (Brazil; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Portuguese; Pass)

When you think about it, can we afford a flat in Central London and still have something left with a basic salary? (Croatia; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Croatian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'Not a' + noun with a passive verb or inverted auxiliary and subject for focus.
Example:
Not a word was spoken by anyone throughout the journey. (Cyprus; C2 MASTERY; 2000; Greek; Pass)

Not a scrap of remorse do they have. (Switzerland; C2 MASTERY; 1993; French; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'What' + noun or pronoun + verb phrase as subject + 'be', for focus.
Example:
What we need is a strong publicity campaign, directed at young people. (Portugal; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

What everyone loved were the special effects and we were very impressed by the use of advanced technological innovations. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Greek; Pass)

What companies care about is money and football players help them to earn it. (Spain; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2005; Catalan; Pass)

What tourists want is to see the most typical things in England, not a hamburger restaurant or a London musical from the back row in the gallery. (Spain; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Spanish - European; Pass)

What students learn are mostly facts and theories. (Korea, South; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2001; Korean; Pass)

What I found particularly fascinating about this story is that it is still exciting and thrilling, despite the plot being rather easy to follow. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use imperatives as pointing devices within texts for focus.
Example:
Note the disadvantages of this transfer. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2002; Greek; Pass)

Notice the difference in the salary. (Ecuador; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Spanish - Latin American; Pass

See the written instructions on the phone for complete instruction. (C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Swedish; Fail)

Can-do statement: Can use 'Wh-'cleft clauses as titles or subtitles, to point to something that follows, for focus.
Example:
Why I think this is a good idea 
People are sensitive, and when they hear about charities, they always want to help. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2003; Greek; Pass)

Why you should choose that event 
If you fund this event, you will gain in two ways: firstly you will help needy people, and secondly you will be admired. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2003; Greek; Fail)

The aim of this is to find out why our biggest customer stopped purchasing from our company. 
How I investigated. First I started looking on the internet in general. (Switzerland; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2009; German; Fail)

How we could benefit in terms of sales 
This drink will be taken by athletes of any kind. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2003; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a non-finite subordinate clause with an '-ed' form, before a main clause, for focus, often in formal, academic or business contexts.
Example:
Compared to other European capitals, there has been a lot done to make riding a bike less dangerous and more comfortable in Berlin. (Germany; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1998; German; Pass)

Outlined below are some essential reasons which justify my choice and should be seriously considered. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2003; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'The' + premodifier + 'thing, fact, point, problem or reason' + 'is (that)' for focus.
Example:
The sad thing about it was that it was actually Richard who said, "Why don't you go on holiday?� (Poland; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Polish; Pass)

The strange thing was that the noise reminded her of someone making a cup of tea. (C2 MASTERY; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

The sad fact is, poverty is very likely to pass down to the next generation in these situations. (China; C2 MASTERY; 1999; Chinese; Pass)

The relevant point is that that personal, almost intimate relationship between the possessor and the thing possessed is at the core of that particular love we all hold for certain things. (Spain; C2 MASTERY; 2000; Catalan; Pass)

The only problem is that they are a little too noisy in the night. (Spain; C2 MASTERY; 2003; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'How', 'Why', or 'Where' cleft clauses as subject, for focus
Example:
How we are brought up forms our character, our thinking and our attitude towards ourselves and towards everybody and everything around us. (Switzerland; C2 MASTERY; 1993; German; Fail)

Where he had gone to was a mystery. (Netherlands; C2 MASTERY; 1998; Dutch; Pass)

How they influenced my life is hard to tell. (Germany; C2 MASTERY; 1997; German; Pass)

Why I think my father is successful is because of his personality, he is very fair about everything,; for example if he sees two beautiful women walking down the street and you ask him which is the nicest of them, he couldn't tell even if one was plain ugly he couldn't. (Sweden; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

[talking about possessions] How people have got their objects is also important. (Sweden; C2 MASTERY; 2000; Swedish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'It' + 'be' + noun + 'that' clause for focus.
Example:
It is Lily who decides to go to the seaside and it is also her who kills the turkey given by a lorry-driver. (France; C2 MASTERY; 1993; French; Pass)

It was Paul who stole the money. (Hong Kong; C2 MASTERY; 1997; Chinese; Pass)

It is Piggy who finds the conch and knows how to blow it. (Denmark; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Danish; Fail)

It is my mother who always plays the role of mediator. (Poland; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Polish; Pass)

It is this silence that gives me the impression of togetherness, for which no words are needed. (Netherlands; C2 MASTERY; 1997; Dutch; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use more than one fixed expression in the front position for added focus.
Example:
But all of a sudden, out of nowhere a bunch of people came running towards him, yelling something he couldn't understand. (Switzerland; C2 MASTERY; 2000; Chinese; Pass)

All in all, taking everything into account, I would suggest that a leisure centre would be the most beneficial as it provides all the facilities necessary to attract and benefit a number of people in the community. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2009; Greek; Pass)

What is more, from my point of view happiness has nothing to do with big things but with small things such as day-to-day details. (Spain; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the affirmative form with 'will'.
Example:
I'll be waiting for you. (Portugal; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Portuguese; Pass)

We will be starting at 12 o'clock this afternoon. (Malaysia; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Chinese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the affirmative form with 'will' and 'shall'.
Example:
However, I shall be attending class the day after tomorrow and I shall cover the work I miss by copying it from John. (India; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Tamil; Pass)

We will be waiting for you at the River's Caf� at 6.30. (Mexico; B1 THRESHOLD; 2004; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the future continuous with 'will' to talk about an event or action in progress at a specified time in the future.
Example:
Tomorrow please come at 4.30 pm because I'll be working before. (France; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; French; Pass)

Tomorrow I'll be studying in the morning, so you can come at 2. (Brazil; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the negative form with 'will' ('won�t').
Example:
I would like you to know that I won't be attending your English class next week. (Argentina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

I won't be coming because my family and I are going on a tour of London. (Malaysia; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Malay; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the future continuous with 'will' as a polite question form, in place of the present simple or future simple.
Example: Will I be needing any money? (Switzerland; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; French; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the future continuous with 'might' or 'may' to talk about an event or activity potentially in progress at a specified or understood time in the future.
Example:
As far as I'm concerned, we should definitely do some additional publicity, particularly for the new offerings which might be coming up. (Netherlands; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2006; Dutch; Pass)

For example, your boss may be calling at 10 pm asking you to prepare a report for next day's meeting. (China; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2010; Chinese; )

Can-do statement: Can use 'yes/no' and 'wh-' question forms with 'will'.
Example:
Will they be holding any activities at night? (Brazil; B2 VANTAGE; 2008; Portuguese; Pass)

Will I be needing any money? (Switzerland; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; French; Pass)

What will you be doing in a few years if now you don't even try to do anything? (Poland; B2 VANTAGE; 1999; Polish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the present forms of 'be' + 'about to'.
Example:
You are not going to believe what I am about to tell you! (Chile; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

I'm in a hurry, my class is about to begin. (Yugoslavia; B2 VANTAGE; 2006; Serbian; Pass)

They are to offer the spectators a view of the variety and the beauty of the world we are surrounded by and which we are about to destroy. (Jordan; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the simple past form of 'be' + 'going to' to talk about the future from a point in the past. ? 'be going to'
Example:
She was going to return it but she saw something very strange, her number was on the screen. (Argentina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

She didn't know what was going to happen. (Turkey; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Turkish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'be due to' and, more formally, 'be to' talk about things that are scheduled or expected.
Example:
Our annual conference for HR managers is due to take place on 10 December 2010. (Austria; B2 VANTAGE; 2010; German; Pass)

However, the demand for products is still estimated as �normal� and is due to increase within the next 6 months. (Russia; B2 VANTAGE; 2009; Russian; Pass)

I am sorry but we are to leave a bit earlier - at about 16.00. (Czech Republic; B2 VANTAGE; 2003; Czech; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the present form of 'be' + 'to'.
Example:
Dear Erica, I am sorry that I cannot attend the meeting at head office as expected, as I am to go on a business trip to New York then. (China; B2 VANTAGE; 2002; Chinese; Pass)

Guideword: USE: OBLIGATIONS AND  INSTRUCTIONS WITH 'BE TO'
Can-do statement: Can use 'be to' talk about future obligations and to give instructions.
Example:
[talking about gorillas] We have no right to do so, because they are to be respected as much as any other living form on this planet! (Italy; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Italian; Pass) 

They are to have their passports with them. (Russia; B2 VANTAGE; 2006; Russian; Pass)

You're to sit in front of the TV and just watch the film. (Argentina; B2 VANTAGE; 2008; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Guideword: USE: IMMEDIATE FUTURE WITH 'BE ABOUT TO'
Can-do statement: Can use 'be about to' to talk about the immediate future, often with 'just'.
Example:
I know what you 're about to answer, and moreover you might be right; (France; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; French; Pass)

My company has a high reputation for manufacturing healthy foods and we are just about to launch a newly-developed healthy snack for children which requires financial backing urgently. (China; B2 VANTAGE; 2008; Chinese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the present form of 'be' + 'due to'.
Example:
I am afraid that July is the only appropriate month, because I am due to start work in August. (Turkey; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; Turkish; Pass)

As some of the members of our team are due to be present at a sales promotion programme next Friday, the marketing meeting once scheduled for next Friday is postponed to next Saturday. (China; B2 VANTAGE; 2008; Chinese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'would' to talk about the future from a point in the past.? 'would'
Example:
I've just bought a new dress, and a beautiful black T-shirt. When I saw them, I thought they would be great for tonight's party. (Spanish - Latin American, B1 THRESHOLD, Pass, 2010)

� we thought that the film would be horrible because of the title but when the film started, the story was beautiful and Mauricio and I liked it a lot. (Portuguese, B1 THRESHOLD, Pass, 2002)

As I saw the advert, I knew it would be a lovely birthday present. (B1 THRESHOLD; 2003; ; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the affirmative form with 'will'.
Example: This summer I will have been working for three years for my company � (Spain; B2 VANTAGE; 2008; Catalan; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the simple past form of 'be' + 'on the point of' + '-ing' to talk about things that were expected to happen soon after a point in the past.
Example:
In addition, when I was on the point of leaving the office, another phone rang. (Greece; B2 VANTAGE; 2002; Greek; Pass)

In fact he simulated his death to escape from the police, who were on the point of catching him fora penicillin racket. (Laos; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Lao; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the simple past form of 'be' + 'about to' (often with 'just') to talk about the immediate future from a point in the past.
Example:
Two days before, I told him that our father was about to buy a brand new car. (France; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; French; Pass)

When I was about to answer the question, I realised that it was not as easy as I had thought. (Sweden; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

Dear Helen, Believe it or not, I was just about to write you a letter when I received yours. (Chile; B2 VANTAGE; 2005; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the simple past form of 'be' + 'due to' to talk about scheduled events in the future from a point in the past.
Example:
It was quite early in the morning, only 7.15 am, and my plane was due to leave in about 40 minutes. (Germany; C2 MASTERY; 1993; German; Pass)

Ten minutes after the time we were due to begin, she arrived. (Spain; C2 MASTERY; 1998; Catalan; Pass)

We have succeeded in persuading the local Council that the factory that was due to be built near the lake was dangerous. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the future perfect continuous to make assumptions about the present.
Example: I do not think that this aspect is really necessary because it is supposed that � you will have been studying very hard to occupy that job �. (Argentina; C2 MASTERY; 2005; Spanish - Latin American; Fail)

Guideword: USE: LOOKING BACK FROM A POINT IN THE FUTURE
Can-do statement: Can use the future perfect continuous to look back to the past from a point in the future and to emphasise the duration of an activity or event.
Example:
Now I am staying in Hastings in England and this month, I will have been studying English for seven months. (Korea, South; B2 VANTAGE; 1999; Korean; Fail)
I think I could have a holiday just in July because I will have been working for my company for one year by the end of the June. (Turkey; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; Turkish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the affirmative form with 'will'.
Example:
I'm sure I will have learned today's lesson by the next lesson. (Brazil; B2 VANTAGE; 2003; Portuguese; Pass)

It seems that the decorative role of clothes will have disappeared by the year 2050. (Kazakhstan; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; Russian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the negative form with 'will'.
Example:

[talking about a cycling trip] Once we have finished, it we won't have done more than 40 km, and there are just another 10 to get to the Lakeside Inn. (Spain; B2 VANTAGE; 1998; Spanish - European; Pass)

Guideword: USE: EVENTS COMPLETED IN THE FUTURE
Can-do statement: Can use the future perfect simple with 'will' to talk about something which is expected to be completed (or not completed) by a certain point in the future.
Example:
There is no problem if you want to leave at 4.30 pm as the match will have finished by that time. (Greece; B2 VANTAGE; 2008; Greek; Pass)

First of all, if you go to work by bicycle every day, at the end of the month you will have saved more money because you won't have spent it buying petrol. (Spain; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Catalan; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the future perfect with adverbs (in the normal mid-position).
Example:

However, sales will possibly have fallen to 5000 units again by the end of the year. (Switzerland; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2006; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the question form of the future perfect simple.
Example: Will he have changed? (Spain; C2 MASTERY; 1998; Catalan; Fail)

Can-do statement: Can use the future perfect simple with 'will' to make assumptions about the present, particularly with 'you'.
Example:
As you will have heard, this year's work experience programme in Britain was in general a success. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2000; Greek; Pass)

All of this is because her book will have included the cultural traditions that go with the dishes. (Brazil; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2003; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the future perfect simple with 'will' as a politeness strategy, often in formal contexts.
Example: [from a formal letter] I hope I will have reassured you. (France; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; French; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the affirmative forms 'will' and ''ll'.
Example:
I will see you soon. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2009; Urdu; Pass)
 I'll come at 7 o'clock. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2006; Others; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'will' and ''ll' to talk about plans and intentions.

Can-do statement: Can use 'will' and '�ll' to make predictions.
Example:
It will be hotter because of global warming.  (2246945_2; PET; Brazil; B1 THRESHOLD; 2007; Portuguese; Pass)
 But, if you go on holiday with your parents, there are some advantages too: you will not have money problems and your parents will not worry about you too much! (Italy; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Italian; Pass)

However, we shall not forget to mention the legal and social consequences of such a merger to the average employees. (Switzerland; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2007; Swiss German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the question form.

Can-do statement: Can use the affirmative form.

Can-do statement: Can use the negative form.

Also you can do whatever you want because there is not going to be an adult there to stop you. (Cyprus; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the past form of 'be' + 'going to'. ? future in the past
Example:

Can-do statement: Can use 'be' + 'going to' with a limited range of adverbs, after the auxiliary be form, in the normal mid position.

Can-do statement: Can use the negative form of 'be going to' to talk about plans and intentions.
Example:

I'm sure I'm not going to live in Kutn� Hora forever. (Czech Republic; B1 THRESHOLD; 2007; Czech; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the past form of 'be going to' to refer to the future from a point in the past. ? future in the past
Example:
She didn't know what was going to happen. (Turkey; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Turkish; Pass)

We were going to meet two days later in the square next to the centre. (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'be going to' with 'be' to make predictions.
Example:

Can-do statement: Can use 'it' + 'be' + adjective + 'for' + object + 'to' + infinitive.

Guideword: FORM/USE: 'IT' + LINKING VERB + ADJECTIVES + CLAUSE, HEDGING
Can-do statement: Can use 'it' + linking verb + adjective + ('that') clause to make an assertion less direct.

Can-do statement: Can use expressions with 'can' or 'can�t' to give focus or add emphasis, such as 'as you can see', 'I can't say', 'I can tell you that', 'as you can imagine', 'I can say that', 'I can assure you that'.

Can-do statement: Can use negative form dare not and daren't +  infinitive without to.
Example: [talking about a restaurant] But many local people dare not go to Lily, because it is too expensive. (Taiwan; B2 VANTAGE; 1997; Chinese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use affirmative form dare + infinitive without to.
Example: I can cook if you dare eat it! (Taiwan; B2 VANTAGE; 2001; Chinese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use semi-modal 'dare' to talk about being brave enough to do something.
Example: Some people object that I have to put up with the rain and other inconveniences, but I think that they are rather jealous because they daren't give up their car. (France; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; French; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'will' + 'be able to' + infinitive to talk about possibility and ability.

Can-do statement: Can use 'be allowed to' to talk about permission.

Can-do statement: Can use 'how dare � !' to express disapproval or offense about something
Example:

Can-do statement: Can use a limited range of expressions with 'be' + infinitive ('be allowed to', 'be supposed to', 'be able to') with present and past forms of 'be' and with modal 'will'.
Example:

I am sorry but I  am not able to meet you next Tuesday. (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; German; Pass)

We were able to choose the songs ourselves and so I liked them very much. (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2001; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'was supposed to', 'were supposed to' to refer to past or future arrangements which may not have happened or may change.
Example:

Can-do statement: Can use the full range of expressions with 'be' + infinitive ('be likely to', 'be due to', 'be meant to', 'be bound to', 'be sure to', 'be certain to', 'be obliged to') with present and past forms of 'be' and with modal 'will' .

Can-do statement: Can use 'was able to', 'were able to' to talk about facts in the past.

Can-do statement: Can use 'be due to' and, more formally, 'be to' to talk about things that are scheduled or expected.

Can-do statement: Can use 'be' (+modifier) 'likely to' to talk about probability.

Can-do statement: Can use 'might as well', mostly to talk about or suggest what we think is the easiest or most logical course of action, often when we cannot see a better alternative. ? 'may'
Example:
Living longer allows you to fulfil the different stages of your personal development, and if you reach the necessary maturity and integrity that corresponds to this stage of your life, you might as well make the best of these years. (Catalan, C2 MASTERY, Pass, 1993)

What should be changed about travelling and spending one's holiday is that the people, in my opinion, should decide on what they want to do during their holidays: If they only want to have fun, they might as well stay at home. (Germany; C2 MASTERY; 1993; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'must' to make invitations.
Example:
You must come and stay in our house too. (Turkey; B1 THRESHOLD; 2007; Turkish; Pass)

You must come and see this restaurant! (Switzerland; B1 THRESHOLD; 2005; Swiss German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'must' with a limited range of adverbs (most commonly 'also') in the normal mid position after the modal verb. ? adverbs
Example:
I must also do the FCE practice test because I will have the FCE test soon. (Chinese, B1 THRESHOLD)

� first you must always watch what you eat � (Mexico; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'must' with a limited range of pronouns ('I' and 'you') to talk about obligation and necessity.
Example:
[talking about a mobile phone] It is very important to me because I must call my parents. (Spanish - Latin American, A2 WAYSTAGE)

I will be at school, so you must arrive at 3 pm. You must take your towel, jeans and t-shirt with you. (Russian, A2 WAYSTAGE)

I mustn't be late. (French, A2 WAYSTAGE)

You mustn't forget your swimsuit. (Spanish - European, A2 WAYSTAGE)

Can-do statement: Can use ellipted 'must' without a subject. ? ellipsis
Example:
[at the end of a letter] Must go now. (Uruguay; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Must be really difficult for you. (India; B1 THRESHOLD; 2010; Panjabi; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'must' with the following verb ellipted where the previous main verb is understood.    ? ellipsis
Example:
You must! It's amazing! (Italian, B1 THRESHOLD)

To sum it up, right now, I take care of her because I must! (French, B1 THRESHOLD)

Can-do statement: Can use 'must' to guess and deduce, most commonly with 'it must be', or 'you must be'.
Example:
Second, it must be boring for you to sit at a computer all day. (Turkish, B1 THRESHOLD)

[talking about moving to another town] You must be so nervous. (Spanish - Latin American, B1 THRESHOLD)

Can-do statement: Can use the question form.
Example:
Is it possible to use the prize next year or must I cancel my trip to India? (Swedish, B2 VANTAGE)

Finally, how much money must I bring with me? (French, B2 VANTAGE)

Can-do statement: Can use 'must' (with a wide range of pronouns and nouns) to talk about obligation and necessity.
Example:
[talking about something the speaker has found] She took it and said we must go and find him. (Poland; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Polish; Pass)

Your parents must learn to let you live your own life � (German, B1 THRESHOLD)

Can-do statement: Can use 'must' to make strong, encouraging suggestions.
Example:
This club has been opened for just two weeks. I mean we must see it. (Czech, B1 THRESHOLD)

[talking about a day out] We must do that again, don't you think?! (Spanish - Latin American, B1 THRESHOLD)

Rome is really fantastic and you must go there! (Italy; B1 THRESHOLD; 2004; Italian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'must have' + '-ed'.
Example:
When I realized that he must have forgotten, I called him up. (Chinese, B2 VANTAGE)

We had lots of fun learning how to ski. It was pretty hard at the beginning. I must have fallen about fifty times. (Brazil; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the fixed expression 'I must say' to give emphasis, usually about something positive.
Example:
I must say that I'm most delighted to have you here with us, Mr. Saramago, and it's with enormous pleasure that my students will hear your words. (Portuguese, B2 VANTAGE)

As I like music a lot I went to as many concerts as possible, and I must say that they were superb. (Germany; B2  ; 2000; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'must' with an increasing range of adverbs (including 'all', 'never', 'strongly', 'first') in the normal mid position after the modal verb. ? adverbs
Example:
To sum up, we must all act immediately because the existence of humanity may be in danger. (Greek, B2 VANTAGE)

But there is one, just one thing we must never forget: we have to be authentic. (Peru; B2 VANTAGE; 2008; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

[talking about a guide book] In addition I must strongly recommend you add something about nightlife. (Russia; B2 VANTAGE; 2002; Russian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use ellipted 'must have' + '-ed' without a subject. ? ellipsis
Example: [from a story] 'Must have fallen out of a car, or somfin'" This was his next thought. (Polish, C2 MASTERY)

Can-do statement: Can use 'must' to ask about obligation and necessity.
Example:
Is it possible to use the prize next year or must I cancel my trip to India? (Swedish, B2 VANTAGE)

Finally, how much money must I bring with me? (French, B2 VANTAGE)

Can-do statement: Can use the perfect form of 'must' to make deductions about the past.
Example:
Of course, India must have changed a lot since Jules Verne wrote his book, but I think that its charm remains. (French, B2 VANTAGE)

I must have looked awful because she asked me whether I was all right. (Poland; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Polish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the fixed expression 'I must admit' or 'you must admit' to express concession.
Example:
On the other hand you must admit that not all ready-made meals taste really good and often they are not as healthy as fresh ones. (German, B2 VANTAGE)

However, I must admit that I completely agree with Chris and consider the mountain road too daring to try. (Russia; B2  ; 1998; Russian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the negative forms of 'must' to talk about what is not permitted.
Example:
You must not hit them or punish them without good reason if you do not want them to become your worst enemy. (France; B2 VANTAGE; 1997; French; Pass)

They must not write on the walls. (Switzerland; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Danish; Pass)

In school for example, you mustn't talk during lessons, and you have to be on time. (Sweden; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; Swedish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'must not have been' (especially with 'easy').
Example:
But I would like to stress that I was really happy that she found another husband, although she had three little children which must not have been easy for him. (German, C2 MASTERY)

Something I have missed on behalf of my father is a bit more tenderness, but again I am guessing it must not have been easy for him to be a post-wartime son of a widow. (Spanish - European, C2 MASTERY)

It mustn't have been more than an hour after the first announcement of the captain that there was a second one. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2001; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'must' with a wide range of adverbs in the normal mid position after the modal verb. ? adverbs|
Example:
There must certainly be other solutions to the problem of the need for space for new houses. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2008; Greek; Pass)

RECOMMENDATION In my opinion our town must clearly use this area to create a park and a playground for children. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2009; Greek; Pass)

I must completely disagree with this statement, since I believe that in all jobs or occupations only the good professionals are able to earn a lot of money. (Portugal; C2 MASTERY; 2005; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can invert 'must' and the subject after negative phrases, e.g. 'not only', 'never', 'nor', to change the focus and give prominence/emphasis.
Example:
Not only must you study really hard during university, but also keep studying afterwards. (Portuguese, C2 MASTERY)

To sum up, my opinion is that education is sacred, necessary and useful to all of us and never must it be characterised as "a waste of time". (Greek, C2 MASTERY)

[talking about personality] Nor must we overlook the human qualities. (French, C2 MASTERY)

Can-do statement: Can use 'needn't have' + '-ed'.
Example:
You needn't have bought me anything! (Spain; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Spanish - European; Pass)

However, you needn't have bothered so much. (France; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; French; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the affirmative form.
Example:
I think you ought to go on holiday with both of them. (Turkey; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Turkish; Pass)

Oh, I'm sorry, my mum's calling and I ought to go. (Argentina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'ought to' with 'you' to give advice.
Example:
Then, if you'd rather go with your friend, you ought to talk to your parents first, and tell them what you think about it. (France; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; French; Pass)

I think that you ought to play tennis or football at the weekend. (Switzerland; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Swiss German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the question form.
Example:
Need you ask? (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2002; Greek; Pass)

Lastly I would appreciate , as I am sure others would too, if the premises were cleaner. Need I say more? (India; 2005; English;)

Can-do statement: Can use 'ought to' without a following verb where the previous main verb is understood. ? ellipsis
Example: Otherwise some students would not get as much specialised help as they ought to. (Germany; B2 VANTAGE; 2010; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'needn't to' talk about a lack of obligation.
Example:
I like summer so much because the weather is hot and we needn't wear a jacket. (Greece; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; Greek; Pass) 

[talking about preparing for a party] As for the music, you needn't worry about it. (Greece; B2 VANTAGE; 2009; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the question form rhetorically in discussion, typically in formal contexts.
Example:
Need I go on? (Cyprus; C2 MASTERY; 2000; Greek; Pass)

Need you work in this way? (Spain; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the negative form.
Example:
You needn't worry about where we can stay. (China; B2 VANTAGE; 1998; Chinese; Pass)

 � when I send an e-mail, I need not worry about the time. (Japan; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; Japanese; Pass)

You needn't go out jogging in the evening because you have already had your exercise. (Sweden; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

Guideword: FORM/USE: DESIRED STATES, WITH 'THERE OUGHT TO BE'
Can-do statement: Can use 'there ought to be' to talk about desired states of affairs.
Example:
The rooms were dirty, there was no room service and there ought to be a lift since the rooms were on the 4th floor. (Sweden; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

� we came to the conclusion that there ought to be some changes to the club�s publicity. (Portugal; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

I think there ought to be more excursions and guided tours. (Sweden; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'ought to' to talk about desired states of affairs.
Example:
Furthermore, we ought to take care of our health by going on trips to not unpolluted places as often as possible. (France; B2 VANTAGE; 1999; French; Pass)

Of course not all zoos are as good as they ought to be, but today we know so much about the different animals that they don't have to get bored in the zoo and we're able to provide them with the environment they prefer. (Denmark; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Danish; Pass)

There shouldn't be any rubbish dumps, all the rubbish ought to be recycled. (Brazil; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'ought to' with 'really' to add emphasis.
Example:
Moreover, you really ought to ask for details about the timetable they've set for schooling hours, just to be sure that its fits the with way of studying you are accustomed to. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2003; Greek; Pass)

This is what almost everyone thinks, but we really ought to think a little bit more about it. (Spain; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1998; Catalan; Pass)

One really ought to know the interests, wishes and demands of the receiver. (Slovakia; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Slovak; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'oughtn't' (without 'to') + verb.
Example: �they will most certainly have a banquet that day... and you oughtn't miss it for the world! (Portugal; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'shall I' to make offers.
Example:
Shall I go and buy some cake and crackers? (Bulgarian, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2009)

The tickets cost �25. Shall I buy you one? (Spanish - European, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2010)

Can-do statement: Can use 'ought to' to talk about something which is likely.
Example:
� the fundamental function of accounting software is to record the numerous ordinary business activities, which may improve the efficiency of the company. Besides, it ought to provide useful information in decision-making. (China; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2007; Chinese; Pass)

You ought not to be hungry. (Turkey; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2000; Turkish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the affirmative form.
Example:
We shall start tomorrow at 2 o'clock. (Marathi, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2006)

I shall be free on Sunday at 6 o'clock in the evening. (Ukraine; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2005; Russian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'shall' with 'we' to make suggestions.
Example:
Tomorrow evening there is Laura Pausini's concert in Turin. Shall we go? (Italian, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2010)

Shall we go to a Korean restaurant after the film? (Korean, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2003)

Can-do statement: Can use 'ought to have' + '-ed' to refer to desired states of affairs in the past.
Example:
Another point, which I think ought to have been better managed, was the boat trip on the Thames. (Poland; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Polish; Pass)


However, the expert that I have consulted claims that this kind of polluted water is the most common consequence when placing gas stations and the government ought to have known that. (Sweden; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Swedish; Pass)

We were taken by surprise, when we didn�t get a tour guide. We ought to have booked one! (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2005; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'ought' + subject + 'not to' + verb to form (rhetorical) questions, often in formal contexts.
Example: And if not, ought we not to learn from the mistakes of the past? (Denmark; C2 MASTERY; 1998; Danish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the negative form 'ought not to'.
Example:
Secondly, there ought not to be a division between rich and poor. (Netherlands; C2 MASTERY; 1999; Dutch; Pass)

We ought not to forget that in the last twenty years the food industry has increased the number of chemicals used in its products. (Uruguay; C2 MASTERY; 2006; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the question form.
Example:
Shall we meet at half past 4 in front of my house? (Japanese, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2008)

What time shall I come? And what shall I bring to the party? (Italian, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2009)

Can-do statement: Can use 'shall' to express commands in very formal contexts.
Example: We therefore need to insist that the agreement is binding and that the contract shall be fulfilled. (Swiss German, C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY, Pass, 2007)

Can-do statement: Can use 'shall' in the main clause after an 'if-' clause  ? conditionals
Example:
Nowadays people live longer than they did in the past, which is very nice and pleasant, but we must be careful because if things get out of hand, � we shall be doomed to live in complete chaos. (Portuguese, C2 MASTERY, Pass, 1993)

I have to inform you that if we do not receive a reply this time we shall take the matter to court. (Poland; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Polish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the negative form.
Example:
You shouldn't miss it. (Thai, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2007)

It is a new flat, so there shouldn't be any problems. (A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Polish; Fail)

I think you should not wear your favourite clothes because they may get dirty. (Thai, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2006)

Can-do statement: Can use 'shall' to talk about plans and intentions, particularly in formal contexts.
Example:
I promise that I shall cover all the work and give it to you tomorrow. (Thai, B1 THRESHOLD, Pass, 2006)

Remember that we shall meet inside the bar. (Russian, B1 THRESHOLD, Pass, 2008)

I apologise for having to miss tomorrow's English class as my cousin's wedding will be taking place ... I shall be attending class the day after tomorrow. (Tamil, B1 THRESHOLD, Pass, 2006)

Can-do statement: Can use 'shall' to make predictions.
Example:
As a result, our town shall have financial benefits, as people visiting the library will visit the city�s shops for their needs. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2009; Greek; Pass)

� we shall probably have several years more to live. (France; C2 MASTERY; 1993; French; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'shall' to seek advice.
Example:
What shall I buy for her wedding? (Slovak, B1 THRESHOLD, Pass, 2004)

[a student writing to a teacher] I am really sorry but I have to travel to Argentina for health reasons. What shall I do with next week's work? (Spanish - Latin American, B1 THRESHOLD, Pass, 2009)

Can-do statement: Can use the affirmative form.
Example:
You should come at 6 o'clock. (Russian, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2009)

Someday we should go there together. (Portuguese, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2010)

We should buy 2 tickets. (Chinese, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2010)

Can-do statement: Can use the negative form.
Example:
This way, students shall not die of boredom or feel that their stay was useless. (Japan; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2000; Japanese; Pass)

Secondly, supplier contracts shall not be omitted. (Russia; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2007; Russian; Pass)

This is, as I mentioned in my letter, only in the event I shall not be able to pick you up at the airport. (Sweden; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the question form.
Example:
Should I wear special clothes? (Farsi, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2006)

It's going to be in S�o Paulo. Should we go by plane? (Portuguese, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2009)

Can-do statement: Can use 'should' to give advice.
Example:
It was only �70. It is pink. It looks very nice. My advice, you should buy this. (Turkish, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2007)

�on Monday, you will have to stay in this class for six hours so you should bring something to eat because you will be hungry. (French, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2006)

You should take some money, because the ticket costs �4.00. (Italian, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2010)

Can-do statement: Can use 'should have' + '-ed'.
Example: I have an appointment. I know I shouldn't have taken it during school time but I had no other choice. (French, B1 THRESHOLD, Pass, 2006)

Can-do statement: Can use 'should' have + '-ed'.
Example:
You should have been with us. (Italian, B1 THRESHOLD, Pass, 2002)

I knew I should have written before. (Argentina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'should' to make suggestions.
Example:
I think we should meet at 2 pm, and my mother will take us there so don't worry. (Spanish - Latin American, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2008)

I think you should meet me around 4 pm at my house. (Thai, A2 WAYSTAGE, Pass, 2008)
