Can-do statement: Can use the question tag form 'shouldn't' + pronoun to make suggestions and ask for opinions.
Example:
When you come back, we should rent some movies, shouldn't we? (Argentina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

I think I should write about the history of our company, shouldn't I? (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2003; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'should' to talk about what is likely to happen.
Example:
[talking about an event] It should be a good day! (Russian; B1 THRESHOLD; Pass; 2009)

�the weather is still warm, so we should be able to visit the beaches and go sightseeing in the evenings. (Portuguese; B1 THRESHOLD; Pass; 2004)

Can-do statement: Can use 'should' to talk about ideal or desired situations.
Example:
British people should eat more vegetables and fruit and avoid fast food! (Italian, B1 THRESHOLD, Pass, 2010)

I think everyone should learn to cook, you never know when you need to cook. (Panjabi, B1 THRESHOLD, Pass, 2011)

Can-do statement: Can use 'you shouldn�t have' (+ '-ed') in polite acceptance of a gift.
Example:
Thank you for the present you sent me, you shouldn't have! (===NONE===, B1 THRESHOLD, Pass, 2003)

Thank you for the money, you shouldn't have sent it. (Uruguay; B1 THRESHOLD; 2003; Spanish - Latin American; Pass

Can-do statement: Can use 'should' and 'shouldn't' without a following verb where the previous main verb is understood.
Example:
Well, have you ever checked your blood pressure? I think you should. (Italy; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

John spent the rest of the day thinking about what he should do. in fact, he wanted to answer and meet her again, but he knew that he shouldn't. (Spain; B2 VANTAGE; 2004; Spanish - European; Fail)

Can-do statement: Can use 'you should have' + '-ed' to emphasise points in a story.
Example:
You should have heard the noise. (Spanish - Latin American, B1 THRESHOLD, Pass, 2002)

You should have seen my face, I was so happy. (German, B1 THRESHOLD, Pass, 1999)

Can-do statement: Can use 'should have' + '-ed' to talk about regrets or undesirable situations in the past.
Example:
You should have been there with me, I had a great time. (Chile; B1 THRESHOLD; 2003; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)


I opened the envelope and read the letter. He had written that he was sorry and that he should not have done it. (French, B1 THRESHOLD, Pass, 2008)

Can-do statement: Can use 'should be' + '-ing'.
Example:
Well, you should be bouncing up and down with joy (just kidding)! (Spain; B2 VANTAGE; 2004; Spanish - European; Pass)

These are the reasons that I believe we should be reading books instead of watching television in our free time and I believe many people believe the same thinks as I do. (Greece; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'should' after 'if' to talk about possible situations in the future.
Example:
If you should change your mind and prefer to take a taxi, you can do it outside the airport by calling this number: 3570. (Italian, C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY, Pass, 1993)

If something should happen, call 112, the local alarm number. (===NONE===, C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY, Pass, 2004)

Can-do statement: Can use 'should be' + '-ing' to talk about present general obligation.
Example:
Wild animals should be running free but I think that zoos today have an important role in keeping them alive. (Sweden; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

Moreover if a car driver has drunk too many alcoholic drinks or is tired he shouldn't be driving. (Greece; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'should be' + '-ing' to talk about expectations.
Example:
The computer systems should be working again once you restart them. (Germany; B2 VANTAGE; 2009; German; Fail) 

However, I think that the situation should be improving in the next 6 months, especially during the third quarter of the year. (Switzerland; B2 VANTAGE; 2009; French; Pass)

[talking about wedding protocol] The groom should be waiting at the entrance for the bride. (Spain; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1998; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'should' with an inverted subject to refer to possible situations, in formal contexts.
Example:
Should you need any further information, don't hesitate to contact us. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Greek; Pass)

Should you withhold any important information or documentation, this could stop any payment to you. (Switzerland; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2002; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'used to' to talk about repeated actions or states in the past that are no longer true.
Example:
When I was I child, I used to go to a small school and I enjoyed it very much. (Italy; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Italian; Pass)

�and she used to come to my house and play computer games with me. (Hong Kong; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Chinese; Pass)

I didn't use to laugh much but since the day we met, I'm always happy. (Turkey; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Turkish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'used to' without a following verb where the previous main verb is understood. ? ellipsis
Example:
She doesn't travel as much as she used to. (Argentina; B2 VANTAGE; 1999; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

I must admit that they did sound quite a lot better than they used to. (Denmark; B2 VANTAGE; 1999; Danish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the affirmative form.
Example:
I used to share my room with my brother. (Albania; B1 THRESHOLD; 2007; Albanian; Pass)

When I was a little girl, we used to be together all the time. (Hungary; B1 THRESHOLD; 2004; Hungarian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the question form.
Example: [talking about a change in eating habits] What did we use to eat? (Netherlands; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1998; Dutch; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the negative forms 'didn't use to' and 'didn't used to'.
Example:
We didn't use to talk to each other. (Brazil; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Portuguese; Pass)

But this year I've met lots of new people that I didn't used to talk to, like Monica and Nina. (Brazil; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'as' + pronoun + 'used to' � to add background to a narrative, often to highlight something unusual.
Example:
She had gone out for a walk in the woods as she used to do every Sunday, with her diary in her hand and a pen in her pocket. (Italy; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Italian; Pass)

He divorced his wife, old flabby Nellie as she used to call her, and proposed to her. (Germany; C2 MASTERY; 1993; German; Pass)

She married a well-off man, and ended up being a housewife, doing piecework for peanuts, as she used to say. (Portugal; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'will' to ask about plans and intentions.
Example:
Will you come by bus? (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Spanish - European; Pass)

Will you come with any friends? (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Basque; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the affirmative forms.
Example:
I will be at your house at 7.30 because I have an appointment before. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2006; Russian; Pass)

I'll come to see you tomorrow morning. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2009; Nepali; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the question form.
Example:
Will you be at home? (France; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2005; French; Pass)

I'm happy because I'll see you tomorrow, but what time will you be here? (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the negative forms.
Example:
Don't worry, you won't need anything apart from some pencils and your art book. (Italy; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Italian; Pass)

I hope it will not be boring! (France; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; French; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'will' to talk about willingness and offers
Example: My mother will get us there, and she will bring us to my house after too. (Brazil; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'will' to talk about plans and intentions.
Example:

Can-do statement: Can use 'will' in the main clause after an 'if-' clause to talk about possible future situations. ? conditionals

Can-do statement: Can form complex noun phrases with 'wh-' cleft clauses, followed by 'be', to give focus.

Can-do statement: Can use a range of compound nouns, as one-word, two-word and hyphenated compounds, formed from verb + noun, noun + noun and adjective + noun combinations.
Example:

I buy wines and ice-cream. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2006; Others; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the '-ing' forms of verbs as nouns, in object position, to refer to activities.

Can-do statement: Can form plurals of countable nouns ending in a consonant plus '-y', by changing the 'y' to 'I' and adding '-es'.

Guideword: FORM: NOUNS ONLY USED IN THE PLURAL

Can-do statement: Can use uncountable nouns with a limited range of quantity words and phrases including 'some', 'any', 'a lot of', 'more'. ? Determiners: quantity

� students are not being educated equally. (Mongolia; B2 VANTAGE; 2008; Mongolian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the present perfect passive negative form (often in the context of reporting). ? reported speech
Example:
�the old-fashioned house which has not been used for twenty years is not a very attractive sight from our town either. (B2 Danish)

Can-do statement: Can use the present continuous passive negative form to refer to ongoing situations in the present.

Can-do statement: Can use the past simple with 'wish (that)' to express regret that things are not different.

Can-do statement: Can use the past simple after 'if' to talk about the possible result of an imagined situation in the present or future.

Can-do statement: Can use 'yes/no', 'wh-', tag and negative question forms with a limited range of verbs.

Guideword: FORM: INVERSION WITH 'NOT ONLY � BUT ALSO'

Guideword: FORM: INVERSION WITH 'NOT ONLY � BUT ALSO'

 This road shouldn't be allowed in the middle of a small town like ours. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

Guideword: FORM: SAME SUBJECT AND OBJECT, SINGULAR

Guideword: FORM: SAME SUBJECT AND OBJECT, PLURAL

I would also spend much more quality time with my family as a whole, which is quite important in itself. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish _ Latin American)

The architecture in itself is beautiful, but the garden is very wonderful, too. (Philippines; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Japanese; Pass)

To begin with, a car, in my opinion, can't be harmful in itself. The trouble is that, nowadays, very fast cars are put on the market and we never know if they are going to be driven by wise people or, instead, by crazy or dreadful drivers. (Portugal; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the pronouns 'you' and 'it' after 'be' in question forms.
Example:
Hi, Mrs. Bishop. How are you? (Skills for Life (Entry 1); ; A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2009; Tagalog; Pass)

Is it OK? (Skills for Life (Entry 1); ; A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2009; Romanian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the pronoun 'it' as a direct object to refer to an object or situation already referred to.
Example:
The maths is boring and I don't like it. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

If you can't find it, call me. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Turkish)

Do you like it too? (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; German)

Can-do statement: Can use the object pronouns 'me', 'you', 'him', 'her', 'it', 'us' and 'them' in the object position after prepositions.
Example:
I really like to learn new words. It's very important for me. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

Sometimes I go with her. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

Can you bring some music so we can listen to it. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; no L1 specified)

I spend my free time with them. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Lithuanian)

Can-do statement: Can use 'as for myself' as a discourse marker to introduce or focus on a personal opinion.
Example:
As for myself, as you can clearly see from my account of this musical event, music still means an awful lot to me, and most probably allways will. (Belgium; C2 MASTERY; 2001; Dutch; Pass)

 As for myself I like taking responsibilities. (Russia; C2 MASTERY; 1999; Russian; Pass)

 As for myself, I grew up during the "internet era", the years when it was spreading to average peoples homes and therefore I can still remember life without it. (Sweden; C2 MASTERY; 2005; Swedish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the pronouns 'I', 'you', 'we' and 'they' after an auxiliary or modal verb in question forms.
Example:
Can I help you? (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic � other)

What do you think about that? (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

Can we have a chat? (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian)

Can-do statement: Can use the pronouns 'me', 'you', 'him', 'her', 'us' and 'them' in the direct object position after a transitive verb.
Example:
I'm very happy that you want to see me. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; German)

I can see her on Saturday at 8 pm. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic)

It protects us from rain, wind and sun. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

You will find a lot of different shops � I hope you'll like them. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian)

Can-do statement: Can use the pronoun 'it' before 'be' to refer to a first person speaker or writer.
Example:
Hello Mrs Bishop. It's Clarisse (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

Dear Cris, it's me, Paarth. (India; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Hindi; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the pronouns 'I', 'you', 'he', 'she', 'it', 'we' and 'they' in the subject position before a verb in statements.
Example:
In my free time I go shopping and I like swimming. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

If you want, you can go inside. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hindi)

He prefers chess. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Singhalese)

My friend's name is Julissa, she is from Ecuador and she lives near my home. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Spanish)

I like my home because it is a beautiful home. It has a big garden and a good sitting room. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Pashto)

I like my front garden because it's very nice and warm. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Czech)

They're nice people. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic)

Can-do statement: Can leave out the subject pronoun with 'hope'. ? ellipsis
Example:
Hope to see you soon. (Key English Test ; A2; Turkish)

Hi! How are you? Hope you are fine. (India; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Hindi; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'it' as an empty subject when there is nothing else to put in subject position, particularly with weather or time.
Example:
It's warm and windy. (Key English Test for Schools; A2; Vietnamese)

Now it 's 3 pm. (B1 THRESHOLD; 2004; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'it' as an object with 'make' to introduce something the speaker or writer is going to refer to.
Example:
This shyness makes it hard for me to speak in public, or even to go out with my friends as often as I should. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish � European)

Other retail companies with cheaper prices and lots of discounts make it impossible for us to do business. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

Can-do statement: Can leave out the subject pronoun with a limited range of verbs, in informal contexts. ? ellipsis
Example:
Must rush now because I have to go out with Paul. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

Sounds great. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

Got to go now. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

Can't wait to hear about your exam. (First Certificate in English; Russian)

Can-do statement: Can use 'one' as a generic personal pronoun in the subject position to mean people in general. ? generic pronouns
Example: If one doesn't live close enough to walk to work, one can choose to get there by bicycle or by car. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

Can-do statement: Can use dummy 'it' with 'appears', 'feels', 'looks' and 'seems'.
Can use dummy 'it' as a subject to introduce something the speaker or writer is going to refer to.
Example:
It is best to spend your time in the countryside. (Preliminary English Test ; B1; Chinese)

It's boring to be at home when you have a lot of free time. (Preliminary English Test for Schools; B1; Turkish)

It's normal that your parents want you to go with them. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

Can-do statement: Can use 'it' with the passive voice where the subject is unknown or unimportant, often in formal contexts. ? passives
Example:
It was considered to be the most important thing to supply every computer with Internet and E-mail access (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

It is hoped that this report will help the club to improve and meet the needs of the whole school. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

Firstly it was highlighted that so many people take advantage of the park, but our survey clearly contradicts this view. (Certificate in Advanced English; Argentina; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2001; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can form a cleft construction beginning with 'it' to emphasise the subject of the main clause. ? clauses
Example: It was my father who took all this away from me. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

Can-do statement: Can use 'this' as a pronoun with singular reference.
Example:
This is a very interesting place. (A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Panjabi; Pass)

I'm very happy about this. (Turkey; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Turkish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'this' as a pronoun to refer back to single things or groups of plural things which have already been mentioned.
Example:
Thank you for this. (France; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; French; Pass)

I went shopping yesterday at Yalerias;. I bought three green T-shirts, a pair of sneakers and some socks. You might ask, why did I buy all this? (Mexico; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'this' as a pronoun to point to or identify single things or entities which are about to follow and have immediate relevance.
Example:
This is my number: 0754 567 78 51. (A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Turkish; Pass)

This is the information about the new art class: the class is on Fridays, and it starts at 4 pm and finishes at 6 pm. (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'that' as a pronoun to refer back to something which has already been mentioned.
Example:
You know that blue is my favourite colour, so we are going to use that. (India; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Tamil; Pass)

It has got a camera, and I like that. (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Catalan; Pass)

They look really nice on me, that's why I bought them. (France; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; French; Pass)

Please try to come after 4.30 because I won't be there before that. (Sri Lanka; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Singhalese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'that's' + adjective to respond to something.
Example:
That's great! (Switzerland; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Swiss German; Pass)

That's a pity! (Argentina; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

That's a good idea! (France; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2005; French; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'that' as a pronoun with singular reference.
Example:
That was amazing. (Peru; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

After that, we can go and drink a cup of coffee and eat a piece of cake. (Mexico; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2003; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'this' as a pronoun to refer to something that is happening now.
Example:
This is the best holiday I have ever had! (Vietnam; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Vietnamese; Pass) 

This is just a short note to ask you if you want to go with me to the ReggaRton's concert. (Argentina; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'this' as a pronoun to refer back to whole clauses or sentences, especially to highlight or continue an important topic.
Example:
To stay fit I'm eating lots of fruit and vegetables, but meat and fish, too. I think you should do this, too, if you haven't done it in the past. (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; German; Pass)

People usually don't care about the cost. Because of this, weddings are more amazing. (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Spanish - European; Pass)

My room seems to be very cold and very unfriendly. I think flowers and pictures change this. (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2001; German; Pass)

Our department currently has a lot of work to do, because there are so many conferences to arrange, and it needs a person to be in charge of this. (China; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Chinese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'those' as a pronoun with plural reference.  ?  noun phrases
Example:
Most of my clothes are lemon, green or orange, those are my favourite colours! (Peru; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Well, those are my ideas but you are the ones that are coming, and maybe you don't like the countryside. (Argentina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2004; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'those' as a pronoun to refer to things which have already been mentioned.  ?  noun phrases
Example:
Those are the things I like the most about her. (Chile; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass) 

I don't really think I'd move, but if I had to, I would love to live in a city like Paris or Rome. I'm very keen on cities like those. (Brazil; B1 THRESHOLD; 2010; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'that's all' to end a letter.
Example:
That's all for now. (Malaysia; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Chinese; Pass)

Well I think that's all. (Peru; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'these' as a pronoun with plural reference.  ?  noun phrases
Example:
These are the most important years for us as teenagers, and they have to be the best years! (Italy; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Italian; Pass)

These are the main things that I can tell you. (Russia; B1 THRESHOLD; 2005; Russian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'these' as a pronoun to refer to something with immediate relevance which has already been mentioned.  ?  noun phrases  ?  pronouns: demonstrative
Example:
He is very clever and generous, and these are the things that I like most about him. (Brazil; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Portuguese; Pass)

There are a few interesting and funny programmes like The Simpsons, Password or Jos� Mota's hour. These are the only programmes I like watching. (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2010; Spanish - European; Pass)

I think that we have similar taste about things like these. (Poland; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Polish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'this one', 'that one' as a substitute for countable singular nouns that have previously been mentioned.
Example:
I don't usually wear dresses but I had to buy this one because I am going to be in a singing competition. (Thailand; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Thai; Pass) 

[talking about a film] I have chosen that one because of my father and brother, they also like it. (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use quantifying determiners + 'of' with demonstrative pronouns  ? determiners: demonstrative
Example:
If you can't, you must choose one of these. (Italy; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Italian; Pass)

And we have to go to Sydney to see all of that. (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2001; Spanish - European; Pass)

There are a lot of programmes in my country, but only some of these are interesting. (France; B1 THRESHOLD; 2010; French; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'that of' and 'those of' as a possessive form, in formal and professional contexts.
Example:
It is widely known that the Russian educational system differs dramatically from that of the European, Asian or American countries. (Russia; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Russian; Pass) 

The strength of our product is that it fits the customers' demands - especially those of middle-aged single consumers. (Germany; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2003; German; Pass)

Therefore, I urge you to publish this letter and reconsider your opinions, which clearly do not reflect those of the general population. (Spain; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2001; Catalan; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'those' as a substitute, followed by a relative clause or '-ed' or '-ing'.
Example:
Moreover, for those who are not interested in sports and who prefer shopping, it would be a good idea to prevent cars and especially lorries from running in the center of the town. (France; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; French; Pass)

In my opinion students should be forced to study all of the subjects, not only those which are enjoyable. (Polish, B2 VANTAGE, Pass, 2008)

[talking about buildings]  Those that can be rebuilt wouldn't be demolished. (Spain; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Catalan; Pass)

The opening hours of the store came in for a lot of praise, with 87% of those surveyed ranking it as good. (India; B2 VANTAGE; 2003; Tamil; Pass)

All those attending are requested to be on time. (Urdu, B2 VANTAGE, Pass, 2010)

Can-do statement: Can use a limited range of pronouns ('all', 'both') with 'of' followed by an object pronoun, to refer to quantity.
Example:
There are a lot of functions but I don't know how to use all of them. (France; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; French; Pass)

It was a brilliant party, and all of our school friends were there. All of them asked about you and they wanted to see you. (Iran; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Farsi; Pass)

My uncle took all of us to the Eiffel Tower. (Vietnam; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Vietnamese; Pass)

I've booked two tickets for both of us, so I hope you'll come. (Malaysia; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Chinese; Pass)

The tickets cost �5 but I can pay for both of them. (France; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2010; French; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use pronouns 'some' and 'any', to refer to quantity.
Example:
[talking about items of clothing] Some were cheap but some were expensive. (Mexico; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

It lasts for 2 hours and we need to bring some erasers because they don't have any. (Greece; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'these ones', 'those ones' as a substitute for plural countable nouns that have previously been mentioned.
Example:
This is only the beginning; there are a lot of things that should be done, but let's just start with these ones. (Italy; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Italian; Pass)

I have got several of those ones. (Hungary; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Hungarian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'some' as a subject and object to refer back to a plural or uncountable noun.
Example:
I saw a lot of people on the beach, some were playing football and some were sunbathing. (A2 WAYSTAGE; 2011; Somali; Pass 

So, I think we will need more meat for the barbeque; if possible, you could bring some. (A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Portuguese; Pass)

I can bring CDs if you need some. (France; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2005; French; Pass)

Guideword: FORM: SUBJECT AND OBJECT PRONOUNS, 'BOTH', 'A FEW', 'ANOTHER'
Can-do statement: Can use 'both', 'a few', 'another' as subject and object pronouns.
Example:
[talking about two types of exercise] Both are going to keep you fit. (Greece; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Greek; Pass)

Both are very good films. (Argentina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2004; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

About going to the city or to the countryside, I think you'll enjoy both. (Argentina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2004; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

I am happy to select a few. (India; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Malayalam; Pass)

Well, in my country there are lots of programmes but only a few are interesting. (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2010; Spanish - European; Pass)

Moving from an area to another is not very simple, but there isn't a problem without a solution. (Lebanon; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Arabic - Levant; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'any' as an object in a negative clause to refer back to a plural or uncountable noun.
Example:
Bring some good CDs. I don't have any. (France; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; French; Pass)

Can you bring orange juice please? I don't have any. (Portugal; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Portuguese; Pass

[talking about taking presents to a party] Did you take any? (Iran; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Farsi; Fail)

Can-do statement: Can use pronouns 'each', 'either', 'enough', 'neither', 'several' as subject and object pronouns.
Example:
As you could guess, each has a very unique style. (Korea, South; B2 VANTAGE; 1997; Korean; Pass)

I would like to enquire if there will be one group or several depending on level of students? (Russia; B2 VANTAGE; 1998; Russian; Pass)

Considering my abilities, there are several that I think you should consider. (Portugal; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Portuguese; Pass) 

Comparing the two firms, both of them go some way towards fulfilling our needs, but neither covers all. (China; B2 VANTAGE; 2002; Chinese; Pass)

[talking about toilets] They are very clean and there are enough so you don't have to wait. (Netherlands; B2 VANTAGE; 2003; Dutch; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a wide range of pronouns ('neither', 'either', 'none') with 'of' followed by an object pronoun.
Example:
Stella and her boyfriend, ... lived with Chuck at the same house, but neither of them knew that Chuck had passed a very complicated exam to be a spy for the United States. (Spain; B2 VANTAGE; 2008; Spanish - European; Pass)

Neither of us could forsee any possible rise or fall in the price of wheat. (Russia; B2 VANTAGE; 2007; Russian; Pass)

How about spending the last couple of days doing some activities like skiing, horse riding and rafting. If you are interested in either of them, have a go. (Japan; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Japanese; Pass)

We didn't know what they wanted. and none of us spoke any Italian. (Poland; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Polish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use an increasing range of pronouns ('some', 'a few', 'any', 'each') with 'of' followed by an object pronoun.
Example:
Of course some of them are closer than others but I love them all. (Uruguay; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

I have shot many photos with my new digital camera and I will send some of them by e-mail for you. (Brazil; B1 THRESHOLD; 2003; Portuguese; Pass)

Children my age are playing too long with their computers.... But only a few of them. (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2010; German; Pass)

So travelling is not at all a problem for any of us. (India; B1 THRESHOLD; 2010; Malayalam; Pass)

Please ensure each of them has a computer, and they can practise for at least half an hour after class. (China; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Chinese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use pronouns 'none' to substitute for subject and object pronouns. ?  pronouns: substitution
Example:
As for disadvantages, in fact, I see none. (Russia; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Russian; Pass)

As for social life organized by the school, there was none . (France; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; French; Pass)

The costs saved without external consultants would be higher than the costs for this course . Opportunity costs: None. (Switzerland; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2000; German; Pass)

I started learning the language when I was seven. Problems when using English? None. (Spain; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'few', 'many', 'most', 'others' to refer to people in formal written contexts, often reports or surveys.
Example:
Few people stop to think about what they are really doing, and few are motivated to work at all. (Sweden; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2005; Swedish; Pass)

Few denied that it was one of the most thrilling and fascinating activities we tried the whole week. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2009; Greek; Pass)

Many express their satisfaction and claim to have acquired a great number of new skills. (Bulgaria; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2007; Bulgarian; Pass)

Many say that extreme sports attract only those who are addicted to adrenaline or those who have nothing to lose. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Greek; Pass)

Some of the students have a few comments. Most were concerned with the planning of the timetable and I hope there may be some changes this year. (Hong Kong; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1998; Chinese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'some of', 'many of' to modify relative pronouns in a relative clause.
Example:
The people of his time were amazed every time they saw his new inventions, some of which were enormous. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2005; Greek; Pass)

By and large, how we eat is influenced by several factors, some of which have nothing to do with your nationality. (Spain; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2005; Spanish - European; Pass)

I am aware that you have a different view on young people's preferences, but I hope this event could give you an opportunity to see some other aspects of young people, some of whom are very active in sports in our club. (Korea, South; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1999; Korean; Pass)

Today we continue this tradition by organising lectures and exhibitions, generally open to the public, many of which deal with Hamburg-specific issues. (Germany; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2006; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can modify 'few' and 'many' with 'very', 'too', 'so' as intensifiers.
Example:
It was on Thursday that I realized how many children were in the centre. There were too many and the day was extremely tiring. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2009; Greek; Pass)

Almost 5000 Greeks died that night, and very few managed to survive. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2000; Greek; Pass)

In recent years, the Internet, which used to be a luxury only used by the very few who had access to it, has become a means of exchanging information. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Greek; Pass)

Sure, some of the motorists changed to bicycles or to public transport - but far too few. (Germany; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1998; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'a lot' and 'much' as a subject pronouns. ? focus
Example:
A lot has changed since prehistoric times. (Netherlands; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Dutch; Pass)

A lot depends on your background. (Romania; C2 MASTERY; 2007; Romanian; Pass)

Much has been said about the need for nuclear weapons, although after the end of USSR and consequently the end of the cold war, this topic was almost forgotten. (Brazil; C2 MASTERY; 1998; Portuguese; Pass)

Much has been said about quality time, but children don't understand this concept, they only know whether you are there or you are not. (Spain; C2 MASTERY; 1993; German; Pass)

Guideword: FORM/USE: 'MANY ARE THE' + NOUN, FOR FOCUS
Can-do statement: Can form complex noun phrases using an inverted form 'Many' + 'are' + noun phrase, followed by a relative clause, as a focusing device.  ? focus
Example:
Many are the causes which have led us to a better and longer life. (Spain; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Catalan; Pass)

Many are the examples of children who hate reading as they believe that it is pointless, but they are not able to judge from a young age. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2008; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'one' as a pronoun to substitute for singular countable nouns which have already been mentioned or are obvious from the context.
Example:
[talking about a phone] I chose the black one with the numbers in orange. (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Spanish - European; Pass)

I bought a new pullover, because my old one is too small. (Romania; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'the one' and 'the' + pre-modifier + 'one' with a complement, to refer to something specific.
Example:
My house is No.8 and it's the one with silver gates. (Malaysia; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Chinese; Pass)

All my friends gave me a present but the one I liked best was John's. (Portugal; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Portuguese; Pass)

Do you remember the one that we saw last week? (Mexico; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

I bought a jacket because the other one that I had was too small, and a t-shirt to use in the summer. (Portugal; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Portuguese; Pass)

My house is the first one on the left. (Cyprus; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Turkish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use determiners + premodifers + 'one'.
Example:
I like my present very much because I needed a new one. (Netherlands; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Flemish; Pass)

I love blue so I bought the blue one. (Turkey; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Turkish; Pass)

It is easy to use and it is smaller than the old one. (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Spanish - European; Pass)

It's better than the other one. (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Spanish - European; Pass)

I have lots of presents, but my favourite one is a CD, Michael gave it to me. (Mexico; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'this one', 'that one' to refer to a singular countable noun.  ?  pronouns: demonstratives
Example:
I met many old friends there, because I was in another judo club before this one and my friends and I left the old one to join the 1.JCF, because we heard that this one is the best in the whole of Frankfurt. (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2001; German; Pass)

I'm thinking about buying a new desk because this one is very old. (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2001; Spanish - European; Pass)

I choose that one, because it is a very good and quiet place. (Argentina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2000; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

This is the only part of "Harry Potter" movies which I don't have, and it's my favourite, so I'm going to buy that one. (Yugoslavia; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Serbian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'one' after 'which' in indirect questions to refer to one of two or more options.
Example:
If you ask me which one I would choose, I would first go camping and then to Disneyland in Paris. (Ukraine; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Polish; Pass)

First of all, you should think of all the advantages and disadvantages of each option and if you want, you can write them on a piece of paper. This way you see which one is the best. (Portugal; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'ones' as a pronoun to substitute for plural nouns which have already been mentioned or are obvious from the context.
Example:
My pillows are getting old and I need new ones. (Brazil; B1 THRESHOLD; 2001; Portuguese; Pass)

Guideword: FORM: NEGATIVE QUESTIONS WITH MAIN VERBS
Can-do statement: Can use 'wh-'words + the negative form of auxiliary 'do' + subject + main verb to form 'wh-'questions.
Example:
You still have this agonising headache. Why don't you go to your doctor? (Polish, B2 VANTAGE)

Why didn't you check with the ticket office first before you wrote your article? (China; B2 VANTAGE; 1997; Chinese; Fail)

Why didn't you say something about it? (Spanish - Latin American, B2 VANTAGE)

Why haven't you told me before? (Bulgaria; B2 VANTAGE; 2008; Bulgarian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use auxiliary 'be' + subject + the '-ing' form (continuous form) to form 'yes/no' questions.
Example:
Are you going to come? (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Catalan; Pass)

Are you feeling better? (A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Are you going to the new art class? (Cyprus; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Turkish; Pass)

Are you doing anything on Friday? (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2010; Chinese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use auxiliary 'do' + subject + main verb to form 'yes/no' questions.
Example:
My favourite song is 'Viva la vida'. Do you know it? (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Spanish - European; Pass)

My bedroom will be blue!! I love this colour!! Do you like it? (Brazil; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Portuguese; Pass)

Yesterday, I went to buy some new clothes at the new store that is opposite my house, do you remember it? (Mexico; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Did you see the football match last night? (India; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Marathi; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use auxiliary 'have' + subject + the '-ed' form to form 'yes/no' questions.  ?  present perfect
Example:
I've just watched a football competition with my family and friends. Have you watched it? (Japan; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Japanese; Pass)

I left my mobile in your house, have you seen it? (Argentina; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2005; Catalan; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use main verb 'be' + subject to form 'yes/no' questions.
Example:
Are you ok? (A2 WAYSTAGE; 2007; Kurdish; Pass)

Where is your dog? Is it ok? (Turkey; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2003; Turkish; Pass)

Are you ready? (Italy; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Italian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use an increasing range of modal verbs + subject + main verb to form 'yes/no' questions.
Example:
Could you meet me at my home at 7 pm? (Brazil; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Portuguese; Pass)

Could you look for it? (Uruguay; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2005; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Would you like to go with me to the U2 concert? (Italy; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Italian; Pass)

Will you come with me? (India; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Assamese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use main verb 'be' + 'n�t' to form negative 'yes/no' questions.
Example:
Aren't you excited about it? (Uruguay; B1 THRESHOLD; 2003; ; Pass)

Isn't he sweet? (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2001; German; Pass)

[talking about a cottage] Isn't it in the mountains? (Czech Republic; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Czech; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use auxiliary 'do' and 'have' + 'n�t' + subject + main verb to form negative 'yes/no' questions.
Example:
Don't you think so? (Japan; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Japanese; Pass)

Don't you like any programmes? (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2007; Spanish - European; Pass)

Don't you think she would be happy? (Argentina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2002; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Don't you know me? (China; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Chinese; Pass)

Haven't you seen it yet? (Argentina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2002; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Haven't they got their own style? (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use modal verbs + 'not' + subject + main verb to form 'yes/no' questions.
Example:
Wouldn't you like to come? (Uruguay; B1 THRESHOLD; 2002; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

I'm going to a picnic next Saturday with my parents, won't you come with us? (Uruguay; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can't you make both? (France; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; French; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use negative 'yes/no' questions to involve the listener or reader by seeking agreement.
Example:
Finally two days ago I found it in my pocket! It's funny! Don't you think? (Italy; B1 THRESHOLD; 2000; Italian; Pass)

They're filming a part of Harry Potter at our school, because our main building is very old. Isn't that great? (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; German; Pass)

You can even just relax and sunbathe while you drink a nice, cold lemonade. Wouldn't that be amazing? (Mexico; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

While we were there, there was also a concert and I got to see Rihanna and Chris Brown! Isn't that awesome? (Tagalog, B1 THRESHOLD, Pass, 2009)

Can-do statement: Can form negative questions with uncontracted 'not' to emphasise a point in an argument.
Example:
Do we not want our children to be as happy as possible? (Argentina; C2 MASTERY; 2002; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Is it not too easy to put the blame systematically on our education? (France; C2 MASTERY; 2007; French; Pass)

Is it not possible to have this, though maybe on a smaller scale, in our everyday living right where we spend the majority of our time on earth? (Switzerland; C2 MASTERY; 2000; French; Pass)

Are they not aware of the negative effects the use of cars has on cities? (Spain; C2 MASTERY; 2010; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can it not, sometimes, be harmful to the world? (Portugal; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Guideword: FORM: REPORTED STATEMENTS WITH 'TELL', PRONOUN SHIFT
Can-do statement: Can report statements using a reporting clause with 'tell' + direct object + 'that-'clause, with a pronoun shift where relevant.
Example:
[about a mobile phone] It's very important to me to have it with me because my brother is in the hospital and my father told me that he will call. (Argentina; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2005; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

My sister told me that this film is very good. (Brazil; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2003; Portuguese; Pass)

Gill told me that you had an accident last week. (A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Italian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can report questions using 'ask' + 'if' or 'whether' + clause, with a pronoun and tense shift where relevant.
Example:
You asked me if I like shopping. (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; German; Pass)

I am asking you if we can change the time of the meeting to 5.00 pm. (Peru; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

A very rich movie producer asked her if she wanted to be in a movie, he said she would get paid 500,000 dollars, she agreed. (Peru; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

I asked her if she wanted to go and have dinner together. (Cyprus; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Greek; Pass)

Renata, a really good friend of mine, told me she was in this club, but she left it some time ago; she asked me if I was interested in joining this amazing club. (Mexico; B1 THRESHOLD; 2003; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

I'm writing to ask whether you're free next Saturday or not. (Vietnam; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Vietnamese; Pass)

Guideword: FORM: REPORTED STATEMENTS WITH 'SAY', PRONOUN SHIFT
Can-do statement: Can report statements using a reporting clause with 'say' + 'that-'clause, with a pronoun shift where relevant.
Example:
My mother said that she can take us there. (Brazil; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Portuguese; Pass)

The teacher said that we have to bring a notebook, a pencil and a rubber. (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can report 'wh-'questions using a reporting verb + 'wh-'word + clause, with a change of pronoun and tense shift where relevant.
Example:
I asked why she was here. (Italy; B1 THRESHOLD; 1999; Italian; Pass)

I phoned and asked what sports we could play in this club. (France; B1 THRESHOLD; 2003; French; Pass)

When we asked why they were filming our school, they said they were looking for a location where they could film some boys and girls leaving the school and so they filmed us! (Italy; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Italian; Pass)

He saw a guy sat there so he sat next to him and asked where the football players were. (Portugal; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Portuguese; Pass)

They filmed it and interviewed a few pupils about what they think about the new swimming pool in the gym and I asked when it would be on TV. (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Polish; Pass)

Guideword: FORM: REPORTED STATEMENTS, PRONOUN AND TENSE SHIFT
Can-do statement: Can report statements using a reporting clause with 'say' or 'tell' + 'that-'clause, with a pronoun and tense shift where relevant.
Example:
I immediately called her to see if everything was o.k. and she said that she had won the lottery and she wanted to give some of the money to me. (Italy; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Italian; Pass)

He said that she was in big trouble because the phone was a bomb. (Peru; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

They said that our school was the most suitable school for that movie. (Turkey; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Turkish; Pass)

He said that it was his phone and he had left it in a cafe. (Uzbekhistan (Republic of); B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Uzbek; Pass)

He said that he was a nuclear scientist and we had met before. (Hong Kong; B1 THRESHOLD; 1999; Chinese; Pass)

Mary told me that she was dating John. (Brazil; B1 THRESHOLD; 2004; Portuguese; Pass)

In the letter, he told me that he was coming to Madrid on the first of June and he asked me if I was free. (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can report speech about events in the future with and without backshifts for words relating to time.
Example:
At the airport they told him to come the next morning. (Switzerland; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Swiss German; Pass)

The trainer was impressed and said that if I play next time as well as this time, I'll be the 'pointing guard' in the team. (Poland; B1 THRESHOLD; 2001; German; Pass)

The letter said that he is coming home next month. (Malaysia; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Chinese; Pass)

Her husband told me that the following day they would return to Germany so that was the last time I saw Sara. (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Basque; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can report requests and commands with 'ask' or 'tell' + direct object and 'to-'infinitive.
Example:
She asked me to come back as soon as possible because my father is seriously ill. (Malaysia; B1 THRESHOLD; 2005; Malay; Pass)

As the concert finished, I heard someone call my name, I turned and there were two men from security who asked me to go up on the stage. (Cyprus; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Greek; Pass)

Dad asked me to help him at work. (Uruguay; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

He told me to go outside the concert hall and wait for him to come. (Cyprus; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Greek; Pass)

I have caught a cold and my doctors told me to rest in bed for a few days. (B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Kurdish; Pass)

They told me to stay in the car and watch them and try to remember their faces. (B1 THRESHOLD; 2007; Slovak; Pass)

Guideword: FORM: DIRECT SPEECH, REPORTING CLAUSE, END POSITION
Can-do statement: Can report speech and thought directly using the reporting verb after the reporting clause.
Example:
�Excuse me Sir, but you forgot your mobile phone," she said. (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; German; Pass)

"I must take it to the police station," she thought. (Argentina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

"Yes of course," she answered. (Cyprus; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Greek; Pass)

�What have I done?" I thought. (Spain; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Spanish - European; Pass)

�What should I do?� she asked herself. (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; German; Pass)

"But where is everybody? Am I alone?" I asked. (Greece; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Greek; Pass)

"What's your name?" he asked. (Mexico; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Guideword: FORM: DIRECT SPEECH, REPORTING CLAUSE, INITIAL POSITION
Can-do statement: Can report speech and thought directly, using the reporting verb before the reporting clause.
Example:
He felt like a worm too and he said to me: "I'm sorry I'm not a good friend". (Italy; B1 THRESHOLD; 2000; Italian; Pass)

Maria answered "Yes!� (Malaysia; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Chinese; Pass)

He answered: "Come with me". (Chile; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Then I thought: "I can't stay in prison". (Chile; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

He asked "Are you Clarice?" I answered yes and then he told me that he was my father. (Algeria; B1 THRESHOLD; 2004; French; Pass)

She asked me "How about we join the club?" (Malaysia; B1 THRESHOLD; 2003; Chinese; Pass)

She thought: "Should I go to the police or should I go back?� (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; German; Pass)

I thought: "Either I talk to her now or I won't be able to talk to her anytime!� (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can report thought using 'wonder' + 'wh-'word + clause, with a tense shift where relevant.
Example:
I always had good times with her and was very impatient to read this letter: I wondered what she had written. (France; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; French; Pass)

I really wondered who he was, but I was embrassed to look at him. (Turkey; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Turkish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can modify the reporting verb with an adverb.
Example:

Guideword: FORM: DIRECT SPEECH, REPORTING CLAUSE, MID POSITION
Can-do statement: Can report speech and thought directly using the reporting verb in the mid position of the reported clause.
Example:
No problem", I thought, "there is only one person". (Botswana; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Vietnamese; Pass)

"We have come together", this man said, "to celebrate our annual meeting and to call our master's ghost tonight!� (Germany; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; German; Pass)

"No problem", I thought, "there is only one person". (Botswana; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Vietnamese; Pass)

"Forgive me, sweetheart", he said, "I will never leave you alone again.� (Poland; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Polish; Pass)

Guideword: FORM: DIRECT SPEECH, REPORTING CLAUSE, INVERTED SUBJECT
Can-do statement: Can report speech directly inverting the subject and verb in the reporting clause where the subject is a proper noun or noun phrase.
Example:
I was astonished when I saw them standing there", said John. (Netherlands; B2 VANTAGE; 1999; Dutch; Pass)

"Who are you?" asked Peter. (Turkey; B2 VANTAGE; 1997; Turkish; Pass)

"Would you mind lending me a part of your newspaper?" said a whispering voice. (Switzerland; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; German; Pass)

What do you think about this? said the Inspector to the policeman. (Spain; B2 VANTAGE; 1997; Spanish - European; Fail)

Can-do statement: Can use the past continuous of the reporting verb to report mental processes, with a finite or non-finite 'wh-'clause in the reported clause.
Example:
I was wondering why I failed. (Greece; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Greek; Pass)

So, he was wondering why we didn't have our letters. (Korea, North; B2 VANTAGE; 2006; Korean; Pass)

I was thinking which of the two would be more interesting, and I prefer to go to "Can Animals Speak", since I love them and I have two. So, I want to know how to communicate with them. (Mexico; B2 VANTAGE; 2008; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

We were wondering what had happened for a few minutes but then we realised that there had been a power cut. (Spain; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Spanish - European; Pass)

While he was thinking how to reply, Jenny took his hand and led him to the school. (Poland; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; Polish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the present simple form of the reporting verb to report information from a written source and a present tense verb in the reported clause.
Example:
First of all, your advertisement says that you have got two great nights in a hotel for us. (Turkey; B2 VANTAGE; 1997; Turkish; Pass)

It says you are asking for people to help in a summer camp for foreign school children. (B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Firstly, your advertisement  tells  us that hotel has two great nights in a wonderful 3-star hotel (Turkey; B2 VANTAGE; 1997; Turkish; Fail)

Guideword: FORM: REPORTED REQUESTS AND COMMANDS, NEGATIVE
Can-do statement: Can report requests and commands with 'ask' or 'tell' + direct object + 'not' + 'to-'infinitive.
Example:
Meanwhile, she told me not to be scared but the place was very... old. (Brazil; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

I told him not to climb the wall but he was so interested in doing movements that he did not listen to me. (Spain; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Spanish - European; Pass)

Arriving there, my father told me not to go far and to stay near him. (Brazil; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can report speech about events in the past with backshifts for tenses and words relating to time.
Example:
She had told me the previous day that she had something important to tell me. (Greece; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Greek; Pass)

We met Daisy at school on the following day and we told her that the previous day we had been at her house; her grandfather had told us that unluckily she wasn't at home. (Italy; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Italian; Pass)

My boss had told me the previous day that an important customer was going to visit the company in the morning. (Spain; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'look forward to' as a fixed expression followed by an '-ing' form or noun phrase, usually at the end of correspondence.
Example:
I'm looking forward to seeing you! (Turkey; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Turkish; Pass)

I look forward to hearing from you. (A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Polish; Pass)

I am looking forward to our meeting. (Sri Lanka; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Singhalese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use an increasing range of verb + particle + preposition + noun or pronoun.
Example:
I can look up to someone in admiration if he (or she) is dedicating his (or her) life to helping other people. (Switzerland; B2 VANTAGE; 2005; Swiss German; Pass)

Other people will see you as a knowledgeable person and they will look up to you. (Greece; B2 VANTAGE; 2008; Greek; Pass)

You should face up to the problem and tell everybody the truth, that you are working too hard. (Poland; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Polish; Pass)

We couldn't just swim and eat ice-cream every day of our summer vacation, so we sat down and came up with the craziest idea ever. (Sweden; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a limited range of verbs + particle + preposition + noun or pronoun.
Example:
I could catch up with the work I miss after school from 3 to 4. (Peru; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

They interviewed and filmed pupils and teachers to find out how they get on with each other. (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; German; Pass)

I'd better stop now and get on with my studying. (Argentina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2010; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

I think that if you want to have a peaceful holiday, you should get away from the city and enjoy the countryside, enjoy nature. (Argentina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2004; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

So you had better go walking or join a club, but don't forget to keep away from junk food. (Libya; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Arabic - Meghreb; Pass))

Can-do statement: Can use verb + particle + preposition, where the preposition is separated from its complement. ? Prepositions
Example:
Anyway, let me tell you what ideas I came up with. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2003; Greek; Pass)

Sometimes in order to feel confident and to be inspired we need a person to look up to. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2001; Greek; Pass)

This you will have to look out for. (Sweden; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

This shows her superficiality, which Kingshaw cannot put up with. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2001; Greek; Pass)

Firstly, let me express that the situation you describe is certainly not something my client could easily put up with. (Czech Republic; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Czech; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use an adverb between the verb and the preposition.
Example:
I am really willing to know more about horses and to learn how to deal properly with them. (Brazil; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

I hope you will look carefully at the enclosed papers and I'm looking forward to hearing from you soon. (Denmark; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Danish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a limited range of verbs, typically reporting, with a 'that'-clause as the direct object.
Example:
I hope that you'll come. (India; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Tamil; Pass)

I think that it begins on 20 or 21 May. (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Catalan; Pass)

My mother said that she can help us. (Peru; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

I heard that you are quite busy right now. (Thailand; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Thai; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use an increasing range of prepositional verbs followed by noun or pronoun objects.
Example:
If you need more information, please look at the information sheet at the entrance. (Switzerland; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Swiss German; Pass)

In fact, our company needs to train some staff on how to deal with the complaints of customers. (China; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Chinese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a limited range of prepositional verbs followed by noun or pronoun objects.
Example:
I listen to music in the living room, and also eat my breakfast, lunch and dinner. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2009; Dari; Pass)

I can look after her if she needs to do shopping and cleaning. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2009; Gujarati; Pass)

I like to walk in the woods and look for mushrooms. (A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2007; Polish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use verb + preposition, where the preposition is separated from its complement.
Example:
In Poland rules that refer to how to dress at school aren't very strict; we don't wear any uniforms, but our clothes have to be clean and nice to look at. (Poland; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; Polish; Pass)

But there is one difficulty which we should deal with. (Russia; B2 VANTAGE; 2001; Russian; Pass)

I would like to give you some ideas of what people in my community want to listen to. (B2 VANTAGE; 2011; Cantonese; Pass)

Guideword: FORM: VERB + DIRECT OBJECT + PARTICLE + PREPOSITION + OBJECT
Can-do statement: Can use a direct object with some prepositional verbs as well as an object of the preposition.
Example: It is widely accepted that being a loyal and trusted individual means that the people around us can trust us or let us in on a secret. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2009; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use verbs, typically reporting verbs, followed by a noun or pronoun as the indirect object and a clause with or without 'that', as the direct object.
Example:
I told you that she has a new car? (Peru; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

You promised me that you will help me to paint my bedroom. (India; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Kannada; Pass)

Nisha told me you had an accident last week. (A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Gujarati; Pass)

Guideword: FORM: VERBS + DIRECT OBJECT CLAUSE WITHOUT 'THAT'
Can-do statement: Can use reporting verbs, especially mental process verbs, with a clause as the direct object, without 'that', especially in informal contexts.
Example:
I hope you can go, buddy. (Brazil; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Portuguese; Pass)

I think I left my phone there, maybe in your kitchen. (Italy; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2005; Italian; Pass)

I think you should go visit the Kuala Lumpur Twin Towers. (Malaysia; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2001; Malay; Pass)

I know it's impossible for you to come during examination time. (Bangladesh; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2004; Bengali; Pass)

My mother said you can come to me at 6.30 pm. (Italy; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Italian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use an increasing range of phrasal verbs + object pronoun + particle.
Example:

I really like shopping for clothes, but I hate trying them on because always when I finish, the shop assistant shows me more clothes. (B1, Portuguese)

Can-do statement: Can use a limited range of phrasal verbs + particle + object.
Example:

I must travel to Mexico City because I won a novel contest and I need to pick up my award. (B1, Spanish - Latin American)

So I opened the envelope and took out the letter. (Germany; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; German; Pass)

She turned off the phone and walked to the bathroom. (Argentina; B1 THRESHOLD; 2008; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use an increasing range of verbs, typically reporting or mental process verbs, with a 'that'-clause as the direct object.
Example:

When I got there, I realised that I wasn't the only winner. (Cyprus; B1 THRESHOLD; 2009; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a limited range of phrasal verbs without an object.
Example:

Shall we go out this weekend to a concert? (Argentina; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2009; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

We can meet up at 2 pm. (Brazil; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2008; Portuguese; Pass)

If you have time, you can come over and I will introduce you to my friends. (Malaysia; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2010; Chinese; Pass)

Every day I can see the sea when I wake up. (Spain; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2000; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a wide range of phrasal verbs without an object.
Example:
Some species are dying out, and keeping such animals in zoos where they can give life to new generations is the only way to prevent them from becoming completely extinct. (B2 Polish)

The following day my grandpa didn�t show up. (B2 Greek)

If you are not good enough at reading, you'll end up wasting your time. (B2, Japanese)

Can-do statement: Can use a limited range of phrasal verbs + object pronoun + particle.
Example:
I will pick you up and arrange everything. (A2 Burmese)

Ring me up or send me an email if you have any questions. (A2 Basque)

You may need to throw it away, it'll be too dirty after painting. (Thailand; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Thai; Pass)

Could you come here by nine o'clock to help me out? (Brazil; A2 WAYSTAGE; 2006; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use an increasing range of phrasal verbs without an object.
Example:
I needed to hang out because my life was too jam-packed and hectic. (B1, Italian)
